text: Sounds of the innerspaces rushing forward. Then a splinter of blue light in the center of the pictur It breaks wide, showing the top and bottom a silhouetted  curtain of razor sharp teeth suggesting that we are insid of a tremendous gullet, looking out at the onrushing unde world at night. HEAR a symphony of underwater sounds:  landslide, metabolic sounds, the rare and secret noises t certain undersea species share with each other. Also, the hint of familiar music, twisted and distorted by the dept

location: BEACH NIGHT SHARK'S POINT OF VIEW RISING OUT OF

text: It is a pleasant, moonlit, windless night in mid-June. We see a long straight stretch of white beach. Behind the lo dunes are the dark shapes of large expensive houses. Hear number of voices singing. It sounds like an eastern  university's alma mater, no longer distorted.

Around a blazing bonfire, a group of young men and women, beer cans (or maybe a keg) in evidence, as well as the bo Spanish leather wine-bag much in favor by beach and ski-b types. The group is swapping sentimental alma maters, weepily si eastern Ivy League anthems - Dartmouth, Cornell, Harvard, Penn, etc. Two young people break away from the others. T are Tom Cassidy and Chrissie. Behind them, there is  considerable necking activity; Tom and Chrissie are more  serious.
Makes a clumsy attempt at snaring Chrissie, cups her from behind. She squirms playfully out of his grasp. We discov he's not especially sober.
Hey! Hey hey! I'm with you, right?

head_text.subj: EXT. ANOTHER PART OF THE BEACH NIGHT

text: Tom and Chrissie are separated from the others, silhouett against the fire, she pauses and looks at the ocean, he i plodding along in the sand, winded. Chrissie runs down the slope of the dune towards the wate leaving Tom reeling atop the dune. As she runs, she is  shedding her clothes. Tom is trying to trail her by her  clothes, like Hansel following bread crumbs through the w But Chrissie is way ahead of him.
C'mon!

She runs headlong into the inviting sea, plunges cleanly  into the water with a light "Whoops!" as the cold water s over her. Behind all this, we continue to hear the sentimental, bee chorus of alma maters. Then we see it -- a gentle bulge in the water, a ripple t passes her a dozen feet away. A pressure wave lifts her u then eases her down again, like a smooth, sudden swell.
Tommy? Don't dunk me...
She looks around for him, finds him still on the beach, h feet tangled in his pants, which have dropped around his  ankles. She starts to swim back in to him.

Her expression freezes. The water-bulge is racing towards her. The first bump jolts her upright, out of the water t her hips. She reaches under water to touch her leg. Whate she feels makes her open her mouth to scream, but she is  slammed again, hard, whipped into an arc of about eight f up and down, submerging her down to her open mouth, choki off any scream she might try to make. Another jolt to her body, driving her under so that only her hair swirls on t surface. Then it too is sucked below in a final and terri jerking motion. HOLD on the eddies and swirls until we're sure it's all over.

In his shorts, laughing to himself, turning in slow stone circles, held prisoner by his windbreaker which seems to  have him in an armlock, as he struggles to free his arm f a tight sleeve. As he turns, we hear the alma maters in t background, from the fire.

A shaft of morning sun blasts through the crack between t bottom of the shade and the windowsill, falling across th heads of the sleeping couple on the bed. It catches Marti Brody right across the eyes, bringing him up from sleep. The job is completed by the clock radio, which clicks on  with local fisherman's report and weather.

Hayes Landing reports conditions  good, with stripers and jacks. The  Coast Guard has no storm warning  from Block Island to Cape Hatteras;  a light chop with freshening winds,  continued clear and mild... (etc.)
Ellen Brody burrows her head under the covers, avoiding  morning for a few precious minutes more.
How come the sun didn't used to shine  in here?
'cause when we bought the house it  was Autumn. This is summer. Feed the  dogs.
We hear the scampering toenails of two cocker spaniels  scrabbling around the foot of the bed. Brody swings out o bed, wearing shorts, socks, and tee shirt.
Right.
Do you see the kids?
Probably out in the back yard.
In Amity, you say 'Yahd.' (she gives it the  Boston sound)
The kids are in the yahd, playing  near the cah. How's that sound?
Like you're from N'Yawk. (gives it Brooklyn  sound)
Give me 30 years, I'll get it.
He leads the dogs out of the bedroom and down to the kitc
Brody enters, sets down some dog food, goes to make coffe starts to fill kettle to boil water, the cold water rushe through and out the burnt-out bottom of the kettle.
Did you burn another kettle? Y'know  you're a fire hazard? This is the  third one!
I never hear the whistle.
Feed the dogs.
Ellen Brody, a tall, attractive blonde woman, enters from upstairs. She's still slightly sleepy, not what you'd cal an "Instant-On" person. Mornings are not her best time.

You want to go through those? (she indicates bag of  clothes) I'm taking them to the Thrift Shop.   It's Marcia Vaughn's pet charity.   Pick out what you want to keep --  it's mostly your city clothes.
(looking through bag,  remembering) I used to wear this to the Garden.  Garbage strikes. Dog shit. Muggers. (he puts it all behind) Ship it.
Don't be silly - You're going to  make summer better for them...
Before Brody can answer, Michael, his oldest boy, enters, holding his hand. There is bright new blood on it, but he sensibly unconcerned. It's a normal childhood scrape.
Cut my hand. Hit by a vampire.
On the swing? I told you not to play  near there until I sanded it down. (to Ellen) See what your son did?
Go upstairs and bring Mommy a band- aid.
Michael goes on out and upstairs. Ellen fumbles in her po and produces Brody's new glasses, which she holds out to  him.
Don't forget these.
Oh, yeah. (he puts them on) How do I look? Older, huh?
I think they make you look sexy.
Brody reacts to this, and bends to kiss her lightly. Then more seriously.
Sexy, hm? What was I before?
Older, sillier.
(as he goes to make  coffee, he fumbles  with the new glasses) I don't want to depend on these  things, y'know - sometimes you can  weaken your eyes.
He looks out the window to the view beyond, discovering s new wonder in the fresh sunlit morning.

head_text.subj: BRODY'S POINT OF VIEW OUTSIDE THE HOUSE

text: Sean, the younger child, is happily romping in the summer air, enjoying the very air he breathes.
Let's see...
The phone rings.
Brody answers one of two phones on the wall.

Brody... yeah, what's up... mmm...  Well, what do they usually do, float  or wash up? Really?... okay, I'll  meet both of you at the beach in (checks watch) ...20 minutes, okay? Okay. (hangs up) First goddamn weekend of the summer.
Michael reenters in bathing trunks, with a towel on his  shoulder, his hand washed, holding a band-aid ready for  application. Ellen takes it, and bandages the finger with care and affection.
There. (to Brody) What was that?
Michael heads toward the beach.
(struggling to get  his shirt on over  his glasses) The office.
He gets his shirt on with Ellen's help. She flicks imagin dust from the badge on his chest.
Be careful.
Here? You gotta be kiddin'.
He gives her a light kiss, starts to go, with his cup.
Love ya.
(kissing him back) Hey Chief. Bring my cup back.
At the door, he takes a windbreaker off a peg and goes on out. We can see the Amity Police shoulder patch as he goes to van parked outside.

Martin Brody's Country Squire police wagon rushes past, t the view to an enormous billboard depicting a typical sum day in Amity. A beautiful model splashes in the gold surf languishing in a Solarcaine sun. AMITY WELCOMES YOU is wr above her flailing arms.
Three small figures in the landscape, walking the beach. surf is rough and there is sea-floor debris strewn about  from the receding tide.

Deputy Hendricks is searching the shore about one hundred yards down wind. Meanwhile, Brody, in his casual police  attire, and Tom Cassidy, still in the clothing we saw him last night, walk down the beach. Brody fingers the missin girl's shoes, purse and clothes. In the daylight, Cassidy misconducts himself, wavering between inflated maturity a tear-blown adolescence.
Christine what?
Worthingsly... Worthington -- no one  ever died on me before.
You picked her up on the ferry.
I didn't know her.
And nobody else saw her in the water?
Somebody could've -- I was sort of  passed out.
Think she might've run out on you?
Oh, no, sir. I've never had a woman  do that. I'm sure she drowned.
You from around here?
No. Cambridge. Harvard. My family's  in Tuxedo, New York, though.
You here for the summer?
Some friends and me took a house.
(genuinely curious) What d'you pay for a place just for  the summer?
A thousand apiece, something like  that. There's five of us. And we  each kick in a hundred a week for  beer and cleaning, stuff like that.
Pretty stiff.
A shrill whistle makes them turn. Hendricks is fifty yard away, on his knees. He blows again, a feeble report this  time.
Maybe that's your girl.
Brody runs toward Hendricks, Cassidy hesitates, then foll with:
(pathetically) You can't make me look -- !

A skein of seaweed garnishes the base of this isolated du The booming waves and fizzing surf make dialogue inaudibl Deputy Hendricks on hands and knees, looking white as a s Brody tells Cassidy to wait at the foot of the dune, and  ventures up. Hendricks stops him with a wave-off, saying  something at the same time. Brody nods understanding and  steps up cautiously and looks down. He adjusts his glasse trying to make sense of what he is looking at. Whatever he sees has a marked effect on his entire physiq Kicking out with his foot, Brody sends dozens of angry  horseshoe crabs into an escape frenzy and they boil over top of the dune and down its slopes. Cassidy takes a few uneasy steps backwards when Brody wav him over. He shakes his head. An awkward moment. Then Cas shuffles forward and up the few remaining feet, his eyes  looking everywhere but down. Brody says something else an Cassidy shakes his head again, eyes out at sea. Brody put his hand gently around the quaking man's shoulder. Nodding, he starts to look down, an inch at a time. He lo He, too, can't make out what it is at first. Then he  understands. The jolt that assaults Cassidy is not unexpected. He fall backward in a sitting position as though shot. Nods yes - it's her. Brody turns and slides off the dune, stumbling  close. Hear his breathing. He looks around, envisioning t week ahead of him....
Chrissie's remains, incomplete from the chest down, horri bitten. (NOTE: See Hooper's dialog in Sc. 91 for complete description of corpse.)

Brody walks through the door and enters his office, holdi a fizzing glass of Alka-Seltzer. Polly, his sixty-one yea old secretary follows close on his heels with her shortha pad of messages and reminders. In the outer office, Hendricks and Cassidy slump into cha sipping from fizzing dixie cups. Brody dips into file drawers for the appropriate forms. H gently turns on Polly, who is behind him.
If this is going to work, you've got  to keep current stuff out here, and  put 'closed' files in there. The  'Pendings' stay on my desk, okay?

Brody slips behind his typewriter, putting paper in the  machine with the effortless ease of years of practice. He obviously no stranger to paperwork. He touch types, hardl ever looking down, checking his notes and listening with ear to Polly. He is affected by what he's seen, but there's work to be  done.

This is in no order of importance,  Chief: There's a meeting on the Amity  Town Council on Aging this Monday  night, Bentoncourt Hall. The Fire  Inspector wants you to go over the  fireworks site with him before he  catches the one o'clock ferry. Mainly,  you have a batch of calls about that  new Karate school.
Brody has just typed the girl's name. He skips the space Cause-of-Death, and just under it types the Next-of-Kin  information he has collected from her wallet.
Searle's Rent-a-Bike, the Rainy Ale,  Tisberry's Hardware... they say it's  those nine-year-olds from the school  practicing karate on all those nice  picket fences.
The phone rings and Polly picks it up.
It's the Coroner. Somebody pass away  in the night?
Brody nestles the phone between ear and collar, listening as he turns to the typewriter.
Jesus, Santos.
Cause-of-Death line rolls into place. The hammers punch o SHARK ATTACK.
leans forward, staring at what he just wrote. Polly cocks her head and removes the phone from his ear.
What's the matter?
Brody takes a breath. A new resolve comes over him.
Polly, I want to know what water  recreation is on for today.
Right this minute?
Brody gets up and moves hastily toward the door.
Cassidy and Hendricks look up as Brody enters.
(To Hendricks) Where'd you hide the 'Beach Closed'  signs?
We never had any. What's the problem?
A local merchant comes through the door.
Glad I caught you. There's a city  truck with New Hampshire plates parked  right in front of my...
Brody pushes past him and out the door.

In the busy center of a town preparing for the big Fourth July weekend, Brody wends his way around sidewalk activit purpose and haste in each stride. As he turns a corner a  little man in a white smock emerges from the Funeral Parl This is Carl Santos, Amity's part-time coroner. Santos lo both ways before crossing Colonial Drive. Brody passes Keisel's Bicycle Rental, navigating an awkwa course through an odd assortment of Schwinns that line th sidewalk in front of a demolished white picket fence. Kei intercepts Brody on the run.
(he stares at Brody's  face) Wait-a-minute. (stares some more) Glasses, right?
Brody nods yes, and starts to move away, but Keisel holds to him.
Look at those fences! Little guys  about eight to ten years old. And  look at this!
He holds up bicycle. The bicycle's spokes are bent and br from some sort of blows.
They did that with their bare hands.
Call me later in the day, okay, Harry?
Santos emerges with Ben Meadows, the stylish, late-thirti editor of the Amity Gazette. Together they cut a beeline the other side of the street.

Past taverns and chowder shacks, past bleacher constructi and July Fourth posters, Brody enters Hardware and Sporti Goods... so overstocked that beach umbrellas, aluminum de chairs, and rainbow beach towels splash a surplus of colo from the display window to the sidewalk.
The store proprietor is busy at work on an inventory list with a mainland delivery man.
Stuff's no good to me in August when  the Pilgrims come in June... (to Brody) Go on and help yourself to whatever  you need, Chief. Can you work the  register?

Brody emerges with enough poster-board, wooden stakes, na paint, and brushes to close every beach on the island. He starts back the way he came when Hendricks shoots up the  street in the patrol jeep. He stops fast enough to call  attention, leans out the window.
Polly told me to tell you there's a  scout troop in Avril Bay doing the  mile swim for their Merit Badges. I  couldn't call them in, there's no  phone out there.
(hands him the sign  material) Get out of there  take these back  to the office and make up some 'Beach  Closed' signs, and let Polly do the  printing.
What's the matter with my printing?

Revealing Larry Vaughn, the Mayor of Amity, exchanging  anxieties with Ben Meadows and Coroner Santos and two oth city Selectmen. They come out in a group, reach the sunli and squint down the street as Brody careens around the co and out of sight. Deputy Hendricks, laden with his arts a crafts, passes them on the street front.
What have you got there, Lenny?
We had a shark attack at South Chop  this morning, Mayor. Fatal. Gotta  batten down the beach.
Vaughn and group exchange horrified looks, but we get the impression it is not in response to the shark-attack news
Who've you told this to, Lenny?
I just found out about it -- but  there's a bunch of Boy Scouts in the  water a coupla miles down the coast  from where we found the girl. Avril  Bay, thereabouts. Chief went to dry  them off.
(to Meadows) Take my car, okay? (to Hendricks) You come with us, Lenny.
I've got all these signs here...
C'mon, it'll give us time to think  about what they're going to say.
They all crowd into a Cadillac El Dorado with Vaughn Real signs on the doors.
A flotilla of twenty exhausted Boy Scouts round a buoy th marks the official course. A rowboat with Scoutmaster usi a bullhorn keeps pace, and urges the boys on.
(bullhorn effect) Let's go, Robbie. You too, Hofner.  Boyle, keep your head up. Alberts,  keep kicking... (etc., ad lib)

location: ON THE BEACH AT AVRIL BAY

text: Two older Seascouts look on with stop watches and clipboa while some Parents shade their eyes from the sun, watchin their offspring. Brody pulls up in the Amity Police jeep, and starts toward the people. Behind him, Vaughn's Cadill pulls up and skids to a stop. In it are Vaughn, Meadows, Doctor, maybe a Selectman, and Hendricks, with his arms s full of sign material. Vaughn intercepts Brody, the other circle around him, effectively slowing his progress throu the sand to the scouts.
Martin! (he catches up with  him) Are you going to shut down the beach  on your own authority?
Do I need any more authority?
Technically, you need the instruction  of a civic ordinance, or a special  meeting of the town selectmen...
(the good guy) That's just going by the book. We're  just a little anxious that you're  rushing into something serious here.  This is your first summer.
Now tell me something I don't know.
All I'm saying is that Amity is a  summer town -- we need summer dollars,  and if they can't swim here, they'll  use the beaches at Cape Cod, or Long  Island.
So we should set out a smorgasbord?
We're not even sure what it was.
What else could've done that?
(to Doctor) Boat propeller?
I think, possibly... sure. A boating  accident.
Some weekend tramp accidentally goes  swimming too far, she's a little  drunk, a fishing boat comes along --
Remember when Fred Ganz went  scalloping in his BVD's? He was going  to swim to New Bedford, he said.
The men all laugh, ad lib their remembrances of this  foolishness.
...and Bill Mayhew almost caught him  in his net...?
(interrupting the  merriment) Doctor, you're the one who told me  what it was!
I was wrong. We'll have to amend the  report.
We never had that kind of trouble  here.
I don't think you can appreciate the  gut reaction people have to these  things.
I was only reacting to what I was  told.
Brody looks out to the water where the scouts are roundin another buoy on the home stretch.

(taking Brody aside) It's all psychological, anyway. You  yell 'Barracuda' and everyone says  'huh'. You yell 'Shark' and we've  got a panic on our hands. I think we  all agree we don't need a panic this  close to the 4th of July.
Vaughn indicates the beach where the Scouts are flopping onto the sand, exhausted, glad to be finished.
I can't work in a vacuum. Why don't  you make Hendricks Chief? His family's  been here since the Puritans -- half  this island are his cousins.
Martin, we hired the best man we  could find.
All ad lib agreement.
We need someone who isn't prejudiced  by old feuds or family ties, someone  who can referee things.
You have our complete support.
Now then. We've got a vandalism  problem we ought to talk about...

The others surround Brody as Vaughn leads the way back to the cars, ad libbing their problem with the little karate choppers. Hendricks puts the signs back into the trunk of Vaughn's  Cadillac. Vaughn waves casually to the Scouts and swimmer who are vigorously toweling off in the background.
In front of Amity's only Music Store, a battered old pick truck pulls in to the curb. Quint and his mate cross sile heading into the music store.

A gently tinkling bell tolls Quint's entrance. Inside the store, a ten-year-old boy is being shown a clarinet. He i playing a mellow low tone, and running "Ode to Joy." Quin looms past him like Neptune rising from the deep, and let his hand drop on the counter with a slap that sounds like club on flesh. The Shopkeeper abandons the little boy and meets Quint.
Hello, Mr. Quint.
Four spools of Number 12 piano wire,  Okay? I ordered them.
(finding them under  the counter) Yessir, right here. What do those  fish do, eat this stuff?
They choke on it.
Without waiting for it to be wrapped, he picks up the gle wire in his gnarled fist, and drops a bill on the counter
Bye now.

No answer from Quint, who stops and sings along with the  boy. The little kid's music degenerates into a series of awkwa squeaks and blurps, as Quint stares at him. Quint continu out the door, threading his way through the people in the street like some great fish. As he gets up into the cab o his pick-up, its door swings open so we can see a crude  stylized shark decorating its side. It slams behind him a Quint gets in and drives away.

A plump jelly-bowl of a woman plunges into the ocean. The enough there to satisfy the most gluttonous shark. Buoyan joyful, she splashes away in abandon. From her, we pan of to reveal other cheerful bathers enjoying that last  uncluttered weekend before the season starts in earnest.
A Man and his dog are romping at the water's edge. The Ma is throwing a stick out into the surf, the dog, a happy  retriever, is bounding into the waves after it.

head_text.subj: TWO YOUNG PEOPLE ON THE BEACH

text: A Girl and her Boyfriend leave their blanket and run for water, playing tag, chasing each other, having a wonderfu time.

He is sitting stiffly in a beach chair, scanning the beac with careful, cautious looks, eyeballing everything that' going on. Around their particular blanket and umbrella are a number adults and their kids, the youngsters gathered to celebra Michael's birthday. Ellen is dishing out ice cream and ca from a cooler chest to the raucous 10-year-olds. Michael' hand is still bandaged.
(an adult) Looks like another big season. Gets  worse every year.
And none of them from the Island.  Just a lot of bother.
Brody (and we) hear a shrill scream from the water. He  stretches to look past the group, to see what's happening out there.

The young lady is disappearing under the water, pulled un the waves by some force. She is shrieking. She pops right again riding the shoulders of her boyfriend, who pulled h under. She's laughing hysterically. Brody is unamused.
(to Taft) What?
Present company excepted, but off- islanders are a pain in the butt.  Pardon my French.
Ellen captures Sean, and holds him playfully, an example.
What about this kid? What if he were  born here. That make him an islander?
Just 'cause a cat has kittens in an  oven, it don't make them muffins.
I'm not a muffin! I'm a boy!
Brody rumples his hair and sets him off to play.
It's Alex Kintner, and his mother, nearby, reading a nove Alex is towing a funny rubber raft, and headed for the wa
Alex! Alex Kintner! Where do you  think you're going?
Water. Just once more, please?
Let me see your fingers --
He holds out his hands.
They're beginning to prune. 10 minutes  more.
Alex starts for the ocean. Behind him, Michael and his ga are also heading for the inviting waves. Brody is watchin them go, his spine rigid with tension.
As Alex and the boys hit the water, we see the man throwi his stick into the waves, his dog swimming strongly after it.
Out beyond the kids and the dog, the Fat Lady is bobbing  around, out way too far, isolated from the other swimmers

A fish's-eye view of the bathers: lots of little kicking  legs, rafts with tasty arms dangling in the blue, slowing circling, favoring one raft (little Alex's). The Kintner  boy's legs and arms are kicking and paddling, producing  bizarre underwater vibrations of more than passing intere Dog goes by, dog-paddling along.
Brody is half-rising, looking out over the water. The Fat Lady is not where he remembered her. He scans the water  anxiously.
Do you want the boys to come in?  Honey, if you're worried...
A Black Object swims across the water. It's the dog, brea against the surf.

It's the Fat Lady, floating, relaxing. A black object swi up to her. It's not the dog. It rears up out of the water It's a man in a black bathing cap. They exchange distant  pleasantries, he strokes away.
Alex Kintner, paddling around, making boat sounds, tootin going "vroom, vroom."
They kiss, embrace, kiss again. Strong stuff. They sink  beneath the waves, knotted in an embrace.
He's trying to salvage a soggy piece of birthday cake, ho it above the water, paddling with his other hand. The ban has come part way loose, and his cut is trailing in the w

head_text.subj: BRODY AND ELLEN ON THE BEACH

text: Ellen is rubbing suntan oil on his back, and he is allowi himself to relax part way. His eyes still nervously scan beach in a constant surveillance. Mr. Keisel is coming ou of the water, toweling off vigorously, exclaiming to hims
(to Keisel) How's the water?
Too cold. I'm going in again Labor  Day. Hope we get this weather next  weekend.
You're very tight, y'know? (digs in) Right there.
Ow. (he sees something) He's gotta be more careful in the  water...

head_text.subj: THE GANG PLAYING IN THE WATER

text: Michael has just been drenched. He splashes back. A big  waterfight ensues, the boys splashing and chopping at the water, shouting battle cries and karate whoops. Alex is  paddling around near them, but not involved with them.

head_text.subj: ALONG THE WATERLINE ON THE BEACH

text: The Man with the Dog is whistling into the ocean, looking for his dog.
Buster! Hey, Buster! Here boy! (whistles) He continues to ad lib calling his  dog, but there's no answer, no dog  in the water.
A huge splash explodes in the water near the gang, an eru of foam and spray that stops everyone cold for a moment. They stop to see who was responsible.
Hey, no fair splashing in the eyes!
Before anyone can answer, another kid (P.J.) renews the  battle, whooping a karate cry, and slashing at the water  with his hand like a little kung-fu warrior, advancing th the waves.

He hits the water, which sprays up suspiciously pink. He  stares at it, surprised. CLOSE ON P.J. His hands are dripping deep pink, the red matting his hai running into his eyes. He looks down. The boys are surrou with a deep pink slick, their little bodies ringed by a  spreading stain of blood.

head_text.subj: SHORE, A TOURIST AND HIS WIFE

text: He's pointing frantically out to sea.
Something in the water. Right there!  Didn't anyone see it?
There's blood in the water.
He leaps to his feet, nearly knocking Ellen over, and sta for the water.
What is it...?
Brody is pelting towards the water. He kicks sand over an annoyed Mrs. Kintner, who looks up, just in time to hear  Brody's bellow.
Michael! Sean! Out of the water.  Everybody out of the water! Michael!  Get out!

His urgency communicates itself to the others. Ellen snat Sean up from where he's been playing in the sand. Other  parents are calling their kids, hysteria mounting. People rush into the water, dragging their children and families bodily out of the ocean. The first kids coming out of the surf are frantically trying to wash the sticky blood off  their bodies. The sight of the red sends the beach into a full panic.

He rushes into the water, up to his ankles, and suddenly  stops, unable to move into deeper water. He is urging Mic out, holding his hands out to his son, who is slogging th the surf towards his dad. He stands there immobilized by water, nervously helping people out of it onto the beach.
As he emerges from the water, Alex Kintner's raft washes behind him, ripped in half, the water pink, the foam spre the stain onto the sand as the wave breaks.
Her voice rising into panic and hysteria with each unansw cry.
Alex! Alex? Alex...!

We are looking at the closed double white front doors of building, through which we can hear a rolling boil of agi conversation. After a beat, they open to reveal Mrs. Kint looking as though she has been visited by the wrath of Go in effect, she has. Her eyes are puffy and swollen from  weeping, her clothing is put on and fastened awkwardly, h gait is not normal. As she walks toward us, Quint enters  with his back to us, they pass without notice; Mrs. Kintn moving out of sight, Quint leading us through the doors i the town hall.

A crowd of angry men and women throng the central hallway their voices a babble of confusion. Many of them are gath around a roughly lettered notice that has been posted on town's official bulletin board. It reads.

head_text.subj: SHARK THAT KILLED ALEX M. KINTNER ON SUNDAY, JUNE 29, ON

text: Vaughn and Brody are on the outskirts of the crowd, which includes Meadows, some selectmen, and others.
Look, I've got to talk to her. This  isn't a contest we want the whole  country entering.
I agree. If she's going to advertise,  I wouldn't recommend out-of-town  papers. Amity people could take care  of this.
I'm responsible for public safety  around here...

Then go out tomorrow and make sure  no one gets hurt. (addressing the crowd) Everybody, could I have your  attention? Since this affects all of  us, I suggest we move into council  chambers, where there's more room...
There is a flurry and a bustle as everyone rearranges  themselves and makes their way into the Amity Selectmen's Council Chambers.

The crowd is thronging into the large room. Already in th room is a solitary figure, standing all the way in the re watching everyone as they enter. Against the back wall is large blackboard used for town business during meetings.
Well, here we all are; anyone have  any special questions?
Is that $3000 bounty on the shark in  cash or check? (laughter from all)
That's private business between you  brave fishermen and Mrs. Kintner. (to Brody) -- Chief --
(stepping in) I'd like to tell you what we're doing  so far. These are some of the steps  I've taken as Chief of Police...
(leading the direction  of the discussion) What's going on with the beaches,  Chief?
All react.

I'll get to that in a minute. First,  I plan to start our seasonal summer  help early, and to use shark spotters  on beaches open to the sea. I'd like  cooperation from local fishermen,  and I've also contacted the  Oceanographic Institute over on the  mainland.
(Interrupting -- sotto  voice to Brody) No need to involve outsiders in our  business, Martin.
Are you going to close the beaches?
Larry and I have also decided to  close the beaches for a short time.
Pandemonium. A collective nerve has been touched.
Only 24 hours!
I didn't agree to that!
That official business could take  all summer!
Maybe it's better to close.
Two opinions have been expressed, and the crowd takes sid vociferously, ad libbing assent or dissent depending on t point of view held forth. THOSE IN FAVOR MR. WISEMAN
We should make sure  there is no danger. MR. HASSETT
I didn't raise my kids to be some  fish's lunch!

head_text.subj: QUINT, THE MAN IN THE BACK OF THE ROOM

text: He has just run his large, coarse fingernails over the  blackboard. He is a large, rough man, a professional fish marked by daily physical toil, About 45 or 50, it's hard tell where the scars leave off and the wrinkles begin. Th is a bit of the showman in him, as well as a bit of kille whale.

(after taking a deep  breath) You all know me. You know what I do  for a living. I'll go out and get  this bird for you. He's a bad one  and it's not like goin' down the  pond chasing blue-gills and tommy- cods. This is a fish that can swallow  a man whole. A little shakin', a  little tenderizing and down ya' go. (a look to Vaughn) You gotta get this fellow and get  him quick. If you do, it'll bring a  lot of tourist business just to see  him and you've got your business  back on a paying basis. (beat) A shark of that size is no pleasure  and I value my neck at a hell of a  lot more'n 3,000 bucks. (a deadly look) I'll find him for three. But I'll  kill him for ten.
Crowd reaction.

(he rises up) The bastard is costing you more'n  that every day. Do you wanna stay  alive and annee up the ten or play  it cheap and be on welfare next  winter. (a final moment) I'm gonna kill this thing... just a  matter of whether I do it now -- or  at the end of summer.
Thank you very much, Mr. Quint, the  Selectmen will take your offer under  advisement

A riffly blur, color alternating with black and white. Th dizziness stops on a book page showing a black and white  rendering of eight species of shark. The banner at the to of the page reads: THE KNOWN AND REPUTED MANEATERS. The riffling begins again, stops on a grizzly photograph scar tissue on six former shark victims. Riffling -- stop Photograph of five Ichthyologists posing on wooden stools framed by the enormous jaws of a prehistoric shark from t family Carcharodon charcharias.
his reading glasses reflecting a stack of twelve library  books, all on the subject of sharks and shark attacks. Th door opens and Ellen enters, quietly, in respect for Brod mood.
Can you stand something to eat?
Love a cup of tea. With lemon.
Ellen walks past Brody to the window and looks out the wi which overlooks the south bay. It is the hour of dusk.
Mikey loves his birthday present.
Where is he?
(with a slight laugh) He's sitting in it.
Brody gets up, concerned, and joins her at the window.
Honey. He has it tied up to the jetty  with a double-knot.
Michael is sitting in the boat, but two of his young scho chums are in the water, swimming around it. Brody opens t window and calls down:
Son! -- Out of the water now!
My boat's neat, dad!
(turning to Ellen) I want him out of the ocean.
It's three feet deep, Martin
(angry now) Michael! Come inside!
It's his birthday present, and you  closed the beach, Honey. I told him  not to go in the water after what  happened yesterday. I don't believe  he'll ever do it again.
I told him not to go out until he  memorized the handbook and the safety  safety regulations, until he was  sure of himself...

Ellen's eyes drift down to the open book, which is displa a reproduction of the famous painting "The Gulf Stream,"  showing a black fisherman in a small dinghy similar to  Michael's being assaulted by the jaws of three man-eating sharks, circling his boat.
You heard your father! Out right  now!

Hendricks and another deputy are assisting Brody. Silhoue of townspeople look on like mourners at a funeral. In the background some workmen are taking down the shutte from a quaint summer cottage. They pause to watch the  declining moments of the day. Three Selectmen also stand watching. One of them seems to whispering bounty news to three youngish men on a nearby  dune. Sounds: Surf and hammering.
Selectman Denherder and his buddy, Charlie, a professiona angler, row towards a tumble-down jetty that leads fifty  feet out into the black water.
You wanna call it a night after here?
It's only two-thirty. What, are you  tired?
Yeah, Charlie, I got my second wind  three nibbles back.

Denherder hefts a bloodstained laundry bag from the  wheelbarrow, revealing about a hundred feet of coiled dog chain and a large patched inner tube. Charlie takes out a monster hook and together they push the wheelbarrow onto rickety pier that is only about five feet across.
(reaching into the  bag) Leg of lamb this time?
Screw lamb -- let's shoot the sirloin!
(a hyena laugh) We're blowin' half the bounty on  bait --

The splintered pier sways to and fro as the men reach the end and start to work. Charlie baits the hook with a mass chunk of sirloin while Denherder secures the loose end of chain to a skinny piling. Charlie then fastens the inner  tube to the chain five feet from the end of the hook.
One more after this, then I'm going  home.
Set?

Denherder tugs the chain against the piling to prove that is. Charlie heaves the bait. Splash! The inner tube follo and both men eagerly watch as it floats seaward, the chai playing out from the wheelbarrow.
Tide's taking it right out.
Charlie lights his pipe and sits back against a piling. H turns on his transistor radio and loops one end around a  fractured board. Denherder paces, bored to death.
You do this all the time, right,  Charlie?
Twenty years.
I can't believe that people pay money  to go fishing. This is really dumb.  This isn't even relaxing... it's  just boring.
Suddenly zipping out, faster and faster, as both men  straighten. Denherder is goggle-eyed.
Hey! What's this?

The chain is coming out so fast that it begins to drag th wheelbarrow to the end of the jetty. A section of chain  tangles around the handle and flips the entire machine in the air. Both men watch dumbfounded as the inner tube, ra out to sea in a wake of white water, suddenly dips under.
Look at him take it!
Do I set the goddam hook?
Let him do it! Go-go-go-go-go!
It is then that the chain whips taut against the narrow  pilings.
A lineup of five decrepit 2 x 4 inch pilings SNAP with a  resounding CRACK.
The end of the jetty is yanked loose. Denherder is flippe like a chip over the side and into the cold night water,  where he manages to snag hold of a splintered timber.
The severed section of jetty, a joined platform of footbo is being dragged seaward with Charlie sitting dazed on to of it, his lit pipe still going.
CHARLIE! JUMP!
Charlie rolls into the water, sputters, turns to watch th flotilla of wood draw away.
looking seaward.
The end of the jetty makes a 180-degree turn and heads ba in his direction.
Holy Jesus Christ!
Denherder steps up on the broken-off piling just to be ou of the water.
Get the hell out! Charlie! Swim!

Charlie, inhaling terror, trying to slog to shore. The je is getting closer. Suddenly, an enormous black fin breaks water like a periscope, making course corrections as it c for Charlie. Denherder jumps from piling to piling, almost losing his  balance on his way to help Charlie. Charlie has reached t last pylon toward open sea, and his hands clamber for a h But --

The algae is too slippery, and his fingers keep sliding b That's when the fin behind him seems to reach up to the s and Charlie manages, with Denherder's desperate help, to  make it safely to shore. The remains of the pier float be up in the inlet.

He is sitting on a little canvas folding chair, eating a  bowl of Cheerios with milk and sugar, watching a panorama ineptitude and greed unfold before his old seaman's eyes. The Amity Pier area is a minor madhouse: out-of-state car elbow local vehicles for parking space at the foot of the dock, and a parade of bounty-hunting townspeople, islande off-islanders, tourist, and others shout and push their w onto the crowded pier, each carrying some bizarre or  appropriate tool for the real or imagined capture of an  unarmed shark of indeterminate size. Rods and reels, drop lines, crossbows, slingshots, harpoo shotguns, rifles, nets and tridents; every fishing supply store and sporting goods house within a hundred miles has been cannibalized to equip this weird array.

head_text.subj: BRODY AND HENDRICKS ARRIVING ON THE SCENE

text: Not having room to bring their police vehicle anywhere ne this mess, they are proceeding on foot into the confusion
...So then Denherder and Charlie sat  there trying to catch their breath,  and figuring out how to explain to  Charlie's wife what happened to her  freezer full of meat.
That wasn't funny.
Some of the locals greet Hendricks with occasional nods o recognition, or an ad libbed "Hi, Lenny," or "Hey, Lenny.
Mrs. Kintner must've put her ad in  Field and Stream.
Looks more like the readers of the  National Enquirer.
An argument is in progress between and Out-of-Towner and Boat Rental Man.
You're charging me double the usual  rent! I didn't come up here all the  way from New Rochelle to be gouged  by some Yankee Cracker!
Prices go up June First every year.  You want a nice cheap, leaky boat,  you go down to the Hamptons. (he sees Brody) Right, Chief?

Making its way through the channel towards the dock is a  sleek, expensive runabout with the name "Fascinatin' Rhyt on the stern. It's professionally handled, and rumbles in it coasts in towards the dock area. Some other boats clea the way for it, zig-zagging in the harbor, causing an ann chop.
Matt Hooper, a bearded, bespectacled young man with an in look, is maneuvering the vessel peering through his winds at the ragtag collection of seafaring loonies all around  him.

Hendricks is mediating the argument between the two men, we can hear a plaintive "But Lenny," from the local as Br sees something that makes him move towards the other side the dock. We see him cross to a little boat built for two three that is settling low in the water as a seventh man  climbs in with his gear.
Hey! You know how many men that's  supposed to hold?
Whatever's safe, right?
What you got ain't safe. You take  some guys off or you don't go out.

head_text.subj: BEN GARDNER AND HIS BOAT, FLICKA

text: Matt Hooper is gliding into the dockside, and Ben throws a line to help make fast as he moors. It's a small island courtesy in an otherwise discourteous mob. Hooper nods  politely as he ties his boat up and steps onto the dock.
Hello.
Hello, back.
He's standing near where Brody is finishing after his  encounter with the chummers. Brody approaches Ben Gardner.
You going out too, Ben?
Might give it a try. That three  thousand bounty beats working for a  living. (yells to his Mate) We ready?

The Mate nods "Yes" and starts to prepare to get under wa Ben and his Mate move away from the dock, headed towards channel and the open sea leaving Felix and Pratt to scamp around the dock looking for another ride.

A particularly awkward moment between a small sailboat an couple of powerboats. The sailboat is trying to hoist sai to make it away from the pier under sail, a real yachtsma conceit, since Hornblower himself probably couldn't navig through this mess. Brody, a landlubber for sure, is tryin to direct traffic to untangle this new mess.
Just back up! No, the other way! Cut  it to your left! Your other left!  The big boat, your front end is out  way too far. Little boat, stay still!
Amidst all this, we can hear the angry shouts of the enta crews.
Dammit, a vessel under sail has the  right of way!
You schmuck, you ain't under sail,  you're goddam drifting!
(stepping in to help) Ahoy, sail! You got an oar? Well,  scull it out!
Tell that stinkpotter to belay!
Tell that ragsetter I'm going to  poke him in the snoot!
Just cast off in turn and make for  the channel, OK?
Thanks.
Brody starts back towards the shore, Hooper is by his sid
Excuse me, I wonder if you could  tell me...
Before he can finish, Brody spots something on shore that moves him to shout to his deputy.
(noticing something) Is that dynamite?
Brody looks, and stops by a boat that's about to cast off He holds out his hand.
If that's dynamite, give it here, or  don't leave port.
Aw, c'mon, it's just fireworks. Sharks  like fireworks, it attracts them.
Hand it over.

The man passes Brody a cigar box filled with dynamite sti Brody tucks the dynamite under his arm, and continues dow the pier. Hooper is still with him. All around them are two distinctly different breeds; the  quiet pros, like Ben Gardner, in well-worn, comfortable  clothes, with efficient, sensible gear, and the amateur  crazies, with all manner of weapons and impractical, sill tourist clothing.
Brody is on the phone, talking to his office, trying to g Hendricks' attention. He throws a handful of washers at t window.
There's a fantail launch out there  that won't make it beyond the  breakwater.
You're tellin' me. I swear, this  town has gone crazy.
Officer, I wonder if you could tell  me where I could find Chief Brody?
Who are you?
Hooper, Matt Hooper. From the  Oceanographic Institute. (holds out his hand)

Ben Gardner's boat is in the lead with Gardner's shouting derisive comments at the crowd headed out from land. The  armada is spread out and moving in a ragged circle, fifte boats in all. One man heaves cherry bombs into the water. smaller boat going in the opposite direction offers us  Barwood, forking spaghetti leftovers into the ocean while his friend pours out a bottle of ketchup. A speedboat chugs by, one of the occupants reading  instructions aloud from a book entitled "Sharks - East Co Vol. I." boatload of impoverished scallop fishermen throw a net  overboard, full of gaps and split ends. The professionals look professional, but the landlubbers out for the $3000  make it impossible for everybody. Collisions are barely  averted.

The Out-of-Towner in a small boat is bent over in a life death struggle, his rod in a tight arc. His buddy leaps a to lend a hand. Twenty yards away in another boat the same struggle ensue This time it's the overloaded boat with the poor scallop  fishermen. Shouts of I'M ON! DIG IN! STRIKE! Then a tangl of tackle springs from the water. They have hooked each o Joy turns to swearing.  Arnold Felix stands up to applaud the mishap, while his buddy Pratt takes careful aim with Remington 1100 12-gauge and blasts at the tackle as if it were a clay pigeon.  The tangle explodes -- Both the Out-of-Towners and the Scallop Fisherman falls o backward --

Three men are aboard, one holding a rod which holds a fas arc. A few yards off stern we see a triangular dorsal fin crossing back and forth, struggling, jerking, the mighty  tail threshing. One man is screaming success, the other t slapping the angler on the back.
They spot it and sour.
Well, get over there! He ain't caught  it yet!

The owner of Pratt's boat throws it forward and Pratt rem a .45 automatic from the holster of his belt. He tests it firing once in the air. As they near the scene of the  struggle, eleven other boats begin converging, until --

Everyone wants to get into the act. They are attacking th threshing beast with all they've got. Pratt uses his  automatic, another blasts point blank with a shotgun. The are occasional water ricochets and the bounty hunters duc from time to time as bullets skip by. Finally, the shark  stops threshing.
Their boat has moved close to the shark, closer than Harr
(exultant) Hand me that pole! Quick!
One of his party in the over-filled boat grabs a gaff and leans out to grab the moribund shark. But Harry won't giv up the line, still reeling in.
Beat it! I hooked him!
How's the family, Harry? (to the man with gaff) Go on and do it!
We split down the middle?
Pratt nods reluctantly. The man swings, lodges the gaff a hauls the shark up onto the gunwale. A paroxysm of cheers from the surrounding boats. Smoke flares are fired into t air.
(a tug-of-war) Let go my shark!

It is a ten-foot tiger, and what a mess -- splattered wit bullet punctures, gashes, bleeding from several orifices. But it is not dead -- it kicks back to life and threatens capsize the boat. Pratt panics and fires six times with h .45. The bullets pierce the shark's head, pass through, a split the fiberglass hull through which a flood of water  rises. Everybody stands up as the boat slips beneath them

The Amity Morgue is also the Amity Funeral Home, a Victor house that normally serves as the community's mortuary. T Coroner, a professional small-town GP, is standing by as  Hooper is speaking into a sophisticated cassette recorder with a headpiece that leaves his hands free for measureme with a calibrator or calipers.
Let's show Mr. Hooper our accident.
With a shrug, the Coroner slides open the drawer.
He is looking down as the drawer slides past him, still m of-fact, turning on his recorder.
Victim One, identified as Christine  Watkins, female Caucasian...

The sheet has just been lifted, and Hooper stares down at the lump on the slab. He stops, turns off his recorder as emotions wage war with his senses. Rationality wins, and turns on the recorder again.

...height and weight may only be  estimated from partial remains. Torso  severed in mid-thorax, eviscerated  with no major organs remaining. May  I have a drink of water? Right arm  severed above the elbow with massive  tissue loss from upper musculature.  Portions of denuded bone remaining. (tense, to Brody) -- did you notify the coast guard?
No, it was local jurisdiction.

Left arm, head, shoulders, sternum  and portions of ribcage intact. (to Brody) Please don't smoke. With minor post- mortem lacerations and abrasions.  Bite marks indicate typical non-frenzy  feeding pattern of large squali,  possibly carchaninus lonimanus, or  isurus glaucas. Gross tissue loss  and post-mortem erosion of bite  surfaces prevent detailed analysis;  however, teeth and jaws of the  attacking squali must be considered  above average for these waters. (to Brody again) -- Did you go out in a boat and look  around?
No, we just checked the beach...
(turns off the recorder) It wasn't an 'accident,' it wasn't a  boat propeller, or a coral reef, or  Jack the Ripper. It was a shark. It  was a shark.

We open close on ugly, open shark's jaws, still oozing bl and gore. As the shark is hoisted up into the air on a gi pole hoist dockside, Meadows is seen passing with his  secretary and a photographer from the Amity Gazette. A cr of returning fishermen from the Armada and townspeople ar gathering around the fish as it is hoisted tail-up into t classic sports fisherman's trophy shot.

Ginny, get this out on the state  wire to AP and UPI in Boston and New  York. Have one of them pick it up  for the national and call Dave Axelrod  in New York and tell him this is  from me and he owes me one... let's  get a picture.

As he and the photographer turn to mob, we see Hooper and Brody arriving from the morgue. Hooper immediately heads  towards the shark, while Brody pauses and we see a look o relief and delight cross his features.
Well, if one man can catch a fish in  50 days, then I guess 50 of these  bozos can catch a fish in one day --  beginner's luck.
(crossing to men around  shark) You did it! Did Ben Gardner catch  this?
Men ad lib "No, I caught it..." "I hooked him," etc.
Okay, everybody, I want to get a  picture for the paper -- could  everyone clear out of the way?
He continues to call directions and move people out of th way to set up his shot. Hooper is measuring the shark.
Could you get out of the shot, young  man?
Who, me? Okay... (he drifts off)

The men (Felix, Pratt, et al) get Brody to join them in t shot. The whole town and the Armada fishermen all line up a classic "high school" graduating class shot with the  victorious fishermen kneeling in front, and the rest of t Armada and Townspeople arranged behind them. Hendricks ho up the "Beach Closed" sign in ironic victory.
Brody spots the Mayor coming towards the dock, and detach himself from the group to join him.
Larry, if you'd see these clowns  leave, you'd never believe they'd  come back with anything. But they  got him!
That's good. That's real good. Ben  Meadows getting pictures for the  paper.
Sure he is.

The men who landed the monster are in a tight cluster,  debating something with Hooper, who is dwarfed by the big beer bellies and ham-fisted hands all around him. It's  probable we don't even see him. The Men ad lib "What kind of shark is this?" "It's a shar like in the movies they got sharks." "It's a man-eater, f sure." "I bet it's a record-breaker," etc.
It's a tiger shark. Very rare in  these waters, and definitely a  maneater.
Hooper enters the circle, and picks up where he left off, measuring the shark's teeth. Others watch him. Charlie an Denherder walk over to the shark. Charlie punches it.
They are walking down to the shark together.
Who's that young man?
Matt Hooper, the specialist they  send down from the Oceanographic  Institute.
(speaking to everyone) I think we all owe a debt of gratitude  to these men for catching this  monster.
Brody and Vaughn are by now near the circle of fishermen, who are surrounding Hooper, raising their voices at him.
Whadya mean, 'Bite Radius?' What's  that?
Teeth are teeth, right?
I didn't say this wasn't the shark,  I just said I wasn't sure this was  the one...
What d'ya mean?

There are hundreds of different kinds  of sharks; makos, blues, hammerheads,  white-tips... any one of them could've  attacked. Look -- shark digestion is  slow. We could open this one up, and  find whatever he's been eating is  still inside.
That's disgusting! This is the  largest, meanest, most vicious shark  ever landed off Amity Island, and a  known maneater!
Let's just cut him open and see what's  inside...
Why not, Larry? We could get a  positive confirmation that way.
Be reasonable, boys -- this isn't  the time or the place to do some  kind of half-assed autopsy on a fish.  Ben... (to Meadows) do you have all the pictures you  need?
Plenty.
Wait a minute...
Felix, Pratt and the others ad lib disagreement. "You're gonna cut up my trophy," etc.
(seeing something  offstage, with low  intensity) I am not going to stand here and  watch this fish cut open and see  some kid fall out on the dock.  Besides... (he indicates off)
We see Mrs. Kintner approaching, dressed in black.

(to Brody) Chief, I'll take responsibility for  this. Boys, cut this ugly sonofabitch  down before he stinks up the whole  island. Harve, tomorrow you and Carl  take him out and dump him right in  the drink.
She seeks out Brody, and stops in front of him.
Chief Brody?
He nods, she slaps him full across the face. There is an  embarrassed silence. Some people leave, following a trend that began with the first mention of cutting open the sha

My Alex was a beautiful little boy  and you killed him. Did you know  that? You knew there was a shark out  there. You knew a girl got killed  here last week. I just found that  out. But you knew. You knew it was  dangerous, but you let people go  swimming anyway. You knew all those  things, and still my boy is dead now  and there's nothing you can do about  that. My boy is dead. I wanted you  to know that.

She stops, unable to continue. Her father takes her arm a leads her away. Pratt, Harry and the others trail off aft her. During the rest of the scene, the camera tightens in Brody to the exclusion of the others.
I'm sorry, Martin. She's in a sick,  terrible state.
Look, maybe this is the wrong time  to pursue this, but I'm not sure...
Before Hooper can finish, Brody's shoulders slump and he  goes slack.
(almost to himself) She's right.
Let's all get out of here, this place  stinks.
I'm going home.
He turns and leaves abruptly, surrendering the dock to Va and Hooper, who eye each other with mutual dis-admiration

Brody and Ellen, Sean and Michael, have all finished dinn Brody's plate is untouched, a virgin meatloaf. His glass, the other hand, is well used, with the remnants of a stif scotch and ice. He is staring across the table at the  youngest, Sean, who makes a face at him. He makes a face  back. They play this game together for a few minutes.
C'mere and give Daddy a kiss.
Why?
Because he needs it.

Sean gives Daddy the kiss. Brody shoos him and Michael of to bed. Ellen, who is feeling progressively more left out with each passing moment, gets up abruptly and clears a f dishes. Brody is not letting her into his world for the  moment, and it shows. There's a knock at the door.
Martin Brody residence?
Ellen opens the door for him.
Hi. I'm Matt Hooper. If your husband  is here, I'd like to talk to him.
So would I. Come on in.
Hooper enters. He's carrying a couple of bottles of wine  which he picked up in town. He sits down near Brody.
Would you like something? Some coffee?
(seeing Brody's plate) Is anyone having this...?
He starts in on it, as soon as someone has indicated "go  ahead."
Dynamite! (to Brody) How was your day...?
Swell.
They exchange a long look that evolves into a slightly  desperate, but shared laughter.
(producing wine) Here... one red, one white.
They laugh some more. Ellen is again left out of it.
(boning his fish) Ummm. Really good.
Brody begins stripping the foil off the wine, screwing in corkscrew, etc.
My husband tells me you're in sharks.
I wouldn't put it that way. But I  love sharks.
You love sharks?
I do. (he tells a story  about his boyhood  and a shark) But you've still got a problem here,  there's a shark just off the island  somewhere.
How come you have to tell them that?
Excuse me, but what are you talking  about? Didn't they catch the shark  this afternoon? It was on the Cape  station news.
They caught a shark, not the shark.  Big difference. I could've proved it  this afternoon, by cutting that one  open and examining his stomach  contents. Also, his bite was too  small.
Brody has the cork out of the wine. Pop.
I was lucky to find that in town --  it's an estate bottled vintage year...
Brody takes the fine wine, and pours it into his drink gl filling the tumbler to the top with ice cubes, diluted sc and the wine.
(as Brody pours) We ought to let it breathe...  Whatever.
Let's all have a drink.
He extends the bottle to Hooper, who politely accepts a t sip. He takes some for himself, and offers some to Ellen.
You too, sweetheart...
Thank you.
(toasting) Here's to your husband, the only  other rational man on the island.  Day after tomorrow, I'll be gone,  and he'll be the only one.
You're leaving?
Going out on the 'Aurora.'
Is that a boat?
Is it! The best-funded research  expedition to ever study the shark...  around the world in 18 months.
Like those Cousteau specials on  television? I think it's for the  kids, but I love them.
Better than Cousteau, or Compagno  with computers, telemetry, Defense  Department funding...
I saw a show with sea otters, and a  big turtle... Mikey loved it. Made  me promise to get him one. Will you  live on the boat?
Yep.
Martin hates boats. Hates the water.  On the ferry to the mainland, he  sits in the car the whole way over.  He's got this childhood thing, there's  a clinical word for it.
Drowning. Lemme ask you something.  Is it true most attacks take place  in three feet of water, around 10  feet from the beach?
Yeah. Like the kid on your beach. I wish I could've examined that shark  they caught...
Something else. Do most attacks go  unreported?
About half of them. A lot of 'missing  swimmers' are really shark victims.
There's a kind of a lone shark,  called, uh...
Rogue?
Yeah. Rogue. Picks out an area where  there's food and hangs out there as  long as the food supply lasts?
It's called Territoriality. It's a  theory.
And before 1900, when people first  starting swimming for recreation,  before public bathing and resorts,  there were very few shark attacks,  cause sharks didn't know what they  were missing?
You could say that.
Brody digests all this; confirmation of facts he has glea in his newly acquired knowledge of the shark species. There is a long pause.
Why don't we have one more drink,  you and I, and then we go down and  cut open that old shark and see for  sure what's inside him, or not.
Can you do that?
I am Chief of Police. I can do  anything I want. (to Hooper) You want to come?
I'm flattered you should ask.
He gets up and they both start out. Ellen watches them go

Dark, spooky shed, with shadows of boats and strange  silhouettes of boat parts and scaffolding. At one end, th large, symmetrical bulk of the shark's carcass lies on a  tarp. A single dark figure is bending over the dead shark The large double doors at one end of the shed squeak open and the Shadowy Figure moves abruptly away from the shark The new entrants move into the shed. It is Hooper and Bro and they are continuing the conversation begun in the car the way over. As the Shadowy Figure moves silently into a vantage point against one wall, he passes through the light from a wind it is Quint, and we only see him long enough to recognize him as he backs against the wall.

...And it was Dartmouth Winter  weekend, and she was Homecoming Queen,  and I was her date; then she got  into the fact that her family had  more money than my family, and she  was right -- her great-grandfather  was in mining, and my ancestors were  Yankee shipbuilders. So we broke up  and I went home with some beatnik  from Sarah Lawrence.
What stinks so bad?
Our friend, the shark.
They bend over the shape like 18th century graverobbers.

We always had a summer place on the  water -- Newport, the Vineyard, so I  figured I'd major in something I  knew about. Oceanography, marine  biology. It was that, or design racing  yachts like my older brother. Hmmm.  He we go. Up the old alimentary canal.  Hold the light.
We hear a slurp and a squish as Hooper produces a big kni and dips into the shark with a major incision.
We open the abdominal cavity and  check the digestive tract. Simple. (he attends to his  work)
From his vantage point, Quint watches, unseen by the two  men. Brody is holding the light, fighting the gag reflex,  fascinated by the bizarre ritual.
What's that?
Half a flounder. Hmmm... a burlap  bag... a paint can... aha!
What? What?!
Just as I thought. He drifted up  here with the Gulf Stream, from  southern waters.
How can you tell?
(showing it) Florida license plate.
He ate a car?
(laughs) No, but Tiger sharks are the garbage  cans of the ocean. They eat anything.  But this one didn't eat any people.  There's nothing here...
He kicks the remains around below camera.
...Nothing.
What do we do?
If you're looking for a shark, you  don't look on land. You go out and  chum for him.
Chum?

Only one sure way to find him --  offer him a little something to eat.  Chum -- blood, waste meat, fish,  anything. They can sense it miles  away. If he's out there, we might be  able to get a closer look at him. (checks his watch) It's a good time, too. They're night  feeders...

We see Brody, looking sick and nervous, holding on anxiou as the "Fascinatin' Rhythm" moves slowly ahead trolling a night. His glasses are already flecked with the white sal of dried seawater. He is wearing a life-preserver. Hooper is at the wheel, a chart spread in front of him, h eyes scanning the sea restlessly, checking the dials and  gauges in front of him as well as the electronic depth-fi and "fish-finder" gear mounted in the cockpit. A green gl shines from the instruments on his face. Two closed-circu TV cameras mounted below the hull flash their pictures on monitors in the dash. In the aisle between the seats is a large container fille with unpleasant-looking bait; Hooper is long-lining for s of shark, and chumming.
(indicating distant  flashing beacon) That's the Cape Light -- we're on  the stretch where he's feeding, if  he's still here.
Brody, bored, tired, and slightly queasy, is trying to  concentrate on anything but the motion of the boat. He st at the sophisticated electronics displays.
What is all this stuff?
(ticking them off) Depth-finder, fathometer, sonar,  closed-circuit TV -- fore and aft --  RDF, single side band... (points to themselves) And two loose nuts behind the wheel.
Can you tell from that if a big man- eater is around?
Sometimes. (indicates display) Look here -- something big, probably  a school of mackerel clumped together.  And staying right with us.
It's blipping and peeping.
Where'd you get all this?
I Bought it.  Both sets of  grandparents set up trust funds for  me; stocks went up, so I don't have  to touch my principal.
You're at the Institute full time?  Or do you have a job?
(a nerve has been  touched) It is a job. I'm not fooling around  like some amateur. It's my life!
We gotta get back soon...

head_text.subj: THE "FASCINATIN' RHYTHM" AS IT SWINGS AROUND

text: The two men looking very small and vulnerable in the open sea, the low-hanging mist obscuring their visibility in t night.
He hears something, his eyes widen. It is the "bump-thump of something scraping the hull.
Hey!
Hooper looks up and cuts the wheel hard, as the same time dropping the engines into neutral, and then reverse. The  sudden change throws Brody to his knees.
What the hell?
It's what they've just run into -- flooded to the gunwale loose debris floating around, a tangle of lines and gear  looking like floating garbage in the cockpit. Hooper's li sweeps across it.
That's Ben Gardner's boat! It's the  Flicka! Ben? Ben!
Hooper cuts his engines and drifts in; he scampers out to the bow of his boat and makes a line fast to the Flicka.

head_text.subj: INSIDE THE COCKPIT OF HOOPER'S BOAT

text: The electronic display is showing increased activity, but only Brody, who is clinging to a support for dear life, c see the blips and hear the chatter. Hooper is leaning out look at the Flicka.
Hooper is examining the Flicka, tying a towline to it.

The light picks its way across the ruined boat. The rail  where a cleat once was is broadly scarred down to the raw timber, and the heady cleat has been torn bodily out of t hull, ripped out screws and all.
Something he has seen moves Hooper.
What happened?
I want to check something. Hold my  feet.
He sticks his head over the side, into the black water.
Don't they have lifejackets or  something? An extra boat?
(surfacing) They must've hit something.
Blip, chatter, blip, chatter.

Hooper moves to get a better look, the boat rocks in the  swell and from his movement, Brody clutches the rail in a death-grip. Hooper goes below decks, getting into his wet suit, buckl on a weighted belt, holding a mask and hot flashlight.
He didn't have a dinghy aboard. I'm  going down to take a look at his  hull.
Why don't we just tow it in?
(hyperventilating) We will. There's something I've got  to find out.
Be careful, for chrissake.
Hooper takes a last few breaths, orients himself, takes a long, hard look at the quiet, open ocean, and falls into sea.

He is studying the surface, trying to follow Hooper's  movements. Brody is forcing himself to stay at the edge o the boat by sheer willpower and grim determination. Brody fascinated by the sea like a bird facing a cobra. He is v much alone. He grasps a flashlight or boathook as a fragi defense against the unknown.

head_text.subj: PAST BRODY'S BACK TO THE ELECTRONICS

text: Beep, chatter, blip.

Hooper descends in a froth of bubbles. Warily he turns a  full circle with his hotlight. At first we see nothing ou of place about the Flicka except that it is lying so low the water. But as Hooper travels the bottom looking for  damage, he comes across a jagged hole two-thirds of the w forward. The hole is about the size of a basketball, and the wood  around it has been bashed and splintered. Hooper explores the hole with his hands, then takes the knife from its sh and begins to dig at something. Whatever it is comes free his hand. As he studies his find, his light wanders upwar pointing directly into the dark hole. Hooper looks up...
Ben Gardner's dead face stares out through the hole in th Flicka, eyes and mouth gaping in frozen horror, his skin  pinched like a prune.

bumps his head in trying to get away, seems to yell throu escaping bubbles. We hear the gasping shout as a bubbling roar in the ears. His mask fills with water as he flails the surface. Miscalculating, he bumps into the hull of hi own boat, shocked, dismayed, his system jangling with  adrenaline shock, his hands open, and the object he pried loose from the hull drifts down and out, falling into the eternity of the ocean bottom. He finally bursts through t surface.

head_text.subj: THE BOAT, HOOPER EMERGING FROM THE WATER

text: He is gasping for breath, his whole body vibrating with  urgency. The salt water in his lungs combines with the  adrenaline in his blood to deprive him of speech.
You all right?
A White! A Great White, I found a  tooth buried in the hull. He must've  attacked... I knew it... Gardner's  dead in there. I didn't see the  mate...
No shark did that to a boat!
Hooper, despite his shock and surprise, is strangely elat almost giddy with the wonder of his discovery.
Jesus Christ! A Great White! Who'd  believe it! We're not talking about  a shark, we're talking about a Shark!
Brody sinks weakly into a chair. Brody huddles in the ste Hooper kicks the engine in with a roar, and still a-shive with excitement, turns the boat and its grim tow back to  port.

Next to the "Amity Welcomes You" billboard is a group of  selectmen, Vaughn, Meadows, Hendricks, and another deputy standing by with paint and brushes. Brody's wagon is ther along with a few other cars. Busy late afternoon traffic starting to pile up as early weekenders and curiosity see slow down to see what's happening. Behind the billboard, Brody and Hooper have gotten Vaughn one side. They are making a closely reasoned presentation him.
There is a kind of shark called a  Great White Shark that every expert  in the world agrees is a maneater.
You're situation here suggests that  a Great White has staked out a claim  in the waters around Amity Island,  and that he will continue to feed  here as long as there is food in the  water.

There's no limits to where he can  strike, and we've had three attacks  and two deaths in the past few days.  It happened like this before, in  1916, when a Great White killed five  swimmers at Jones Beach, in Long  Island.
A shark's attack is stimulated by  the kind of splashing and activity  that occurs whenever humans go  swimming -- you can't avoid it!
A 4th of July beach is like ringing  a dinner bell, for Chrissake!
I just pulled a shark tooth the size  of a shot glass out of the hull of a  wrecked boat out there.
We towed Ben Gardner's boat in, Larry;  he was dead and his boat was all  chewed up.
Is that tooth here? Did anyone see  it? HOOPER
I don't have it.
What kind of a shark did you say it  was?
Carcaradon carcharias. A Great White.
Well, I'm not going to commit economic  suicide on that flimsy evidence. We  depend on the summer people for our  lives, and if our beaches are closed,  then we're all finished.

We have got to close the beaches. We  have got to get someone to kill the  shark, we need non-corrosive mesh  netting, we need scientific support...  It's gonna cost money just to keep  the nuts out and save what we have.
I don't thing either of you is  familiar with our problems...

I'm familiar with the fact that you  are going to ignore this thing until  it swims up and bites you on the  ass! There are only two ways to solve  this thing: you can kill it, or you  can cut off its food supply...
That means closing the beaches.
Come here, I want to show you  something.

He leads Brody around to the front of the billboard, on w we see that some pranksters have painted a huge shark fin the water behind the swimmer, so she looks now like a fra bather fleeing a pursuing monster.
Sick vandalism! Brody, that's a  deliberate mutilation of a public  service message! I want those little  paint-happy bastards caught and hung  up by their baby Buster Browns!
(who has followed  them around) That's it! I'm standing here arguing  with a guy who can't wait to be a  hot lunch. Goodbye.
Wait a minute! I need you.
Out there is a Perfect Engine, an  Eating Machine that is a miracle of  evolution -- it swims and eats and  that's all. Look at that! Those  proportions are correct. (indicates fin) I know sharks.
You'd love to prove that. Getting  your name in the National Geographic.
Larry, we can re-open the beaches in  August.

August! Tomorrow is the 4th of July,  and we are going to open for business.   It's going to be our best summer in  years. If you're so concerned about  the beaches, you two, you do whatever  you have to to keep them safe, but  with you or without you, the beaches  stay open this weekend.

Two cavernous iron doors. Then a crack of vertical light six burly crewmen muscle them apart. The Amity ferry land is approaching, people in colorful outfits waiting docksi for the first filled-to-capacity shuttle of the summer se and -- Bach's Little Fugue is the musical accompaniment to this  wholly visual montage of disembarkation. The next two min should be treated like a "short film" taking into account all of the colors, episodes, faces and behavior of a vari of Americans who colonize Eastern resort communities for ninety-day season. Intercut with this montage is Brody's home, where Ellen,  Hooper and Brody are in sweaty, gritty all-out effort to  enlist some support. Elements in this montage include: A.  A train of cars trundling down the ramp, bumper to bu B.  Young Beautiful People from Princeton, Yale, NYU, wea knapsacks, toting luggage, babies riding in papoose rigs, energized children, senior citizens holding hands on the  pedestrian ramp, a few wheelchairs. C.  Hooper, bent over the phone: "I know it's a long week could you get me his home phone number? D.  Sidewalk vendors hawking "Shark Killed" souvenirs, bi photo "Personality Posters" of the dead tiger shark hung the dock. E.  Brody: "You're acting senior officer? Where's Chief P Officer Feldman? Where's the Coast Guard Executive Office F.  Souvenir stands selling Genuine Sharks Teeth from The Amity Killer Shark, Captured This Week. G.  Amity Cab Company, small blue Toyotas lined up with t college student drivers like a bomber wing. H.  Hooper:  "Well then, operator, could you try him in t dining room?" I.  Brody: "All I get is a recording. Is there some other number I could try...?" J.  Station wagons with pale winter faces pressed anxious to the window. Cadillacs with Rear Admirals at the helm,  their wives with blue hair remembering the way from years before. K.  Hooper: "When did he check out? Did he leave another  phone number?" L.  Brody: "How can I reach him in Chambers if he's not i Chambers?" M.  Little Karate Hands breaking picket fences. N.  Some local delinquents about 10 or 12 years old, towi behind their bicycles a little dead sand shark with signs "Amity Monster Shark." "Killed Here." 5 Cents a Hit." Etc Then six blonde and tanned Coney Island meatballs descend the ramp. They all wear Men's Club Lifeguard patches and  matching collegiate windbreakers. They scour the landing, looking for someone to save. The boat is empty. Everybody heading inland, anticipating the best Fourth of July ever. Already there is debris on docks and the cleaning crew works away at it.
As Bach's Little Fugue ends, the six burly crewmen lean t combined weight against the Cathedral doors, closing out light and locking in the trade. The doors latch shut with resounding clang!

He is studying everything, trying to make sure he has it  covered as well as possible. He almost doesn't hear the  approaching roar of a small helicopter until it settles d behind him, and a Flying Officer gets out, starched, pres fatigues, a flawless fatigue baseball cap, and slick dark aviator's sunglasses. The Steve Canyon of Amity. He prese Brody with a clipboard.
Martin Brody? (Brody nods) I'll need your signature here...  here... and here.
What is this?
Authorization for direct payment of  flight expenses not directly connected  to a normal mission of this command. (Brody doesn't  understand) You pay for the gas.
Brody signs. The Officer shakes his head as Brody makes a error.
I signed on the wrong line...
Just erase your signature and initial  your erasure.

Brody complies, shaking his head. The Officer snaps him a salute, jogs lightly back to his idling copter, buckles i and gives Brody a "thumbs up" as he lifts off in a flurry sand and ice-cream wrappers.

And this is it -- the Dawn Patrol, the only forces that t frantic phone calling produced. Hendricks, and the regula summer extra deputies. The lifeguards. Half a dozen state troopers. Some deputies from neighboring towns, and a Coa Guard ensign with a handful of regulars in work dungarees Some of Hooper's friends from the institute. Brody and Hooper, badly in need of sleep, are watching th crew straggle in. Already the first of the holiday beach- goers are piling out of their cars in a brightly colored  cascade of beach balls, umbrellas, blankets, portable bar ques, radios, sun visors, reflectors, rafts, balls, tubes and newspapers. Hooper watches one such group: A Family of Ten getting ou of a camper-van. He watches in dismay as the family bumbl onto the beach for a day of fun in the sun. Brody addresses his troops, such as they are.
I want to thank you guys from local  agencies for cooperating, and I hope  we won't actually be needing your  services. But I'm glad to have you  here.
The Men ad lib responses: "Happy to do it," "Any time,"  "When's lunch?" "I hate holidays," etc.
I want to get our lines and repellent  out, so we better shove off.
He nods to his men, who head for some Boston Whalers (or  similar boat with surf-riding capability) and push off in the surf to patrol the swimming areas.
(a last caution) We're all on one channel, so let's  keep radio traffic to a minimum,  okay?
Everyone kind of nods acknowledgment.
I hope we get some more help.
I wish it would rain...

In a shed near the bandstand, a half-dozen pinball and ar machines sucking quarters from holiday beach-goers. A  mechanical shark traverses the screen, is hit with an ele harpoon and red "blood" blossoms from its side, indicatin hit. Sounds of electronic gadgetry, people having fun. Meadows there writing it all up for the paper. A move away from t screen of this particular machine reveals the arcade, the parking lot, and, finally, the beginnings of the panorama the beach that July 4th has created.

four foot surfer's swell curls and crashes on shore,  riderless. The broad sandy beach is a mosaic of summer co as one thousand vacationers practice fun in the sun, but in the water. Hot dog stands and ice cream vendors are  everywhere.
A half-dozen lookout lofts. As many handsome lifeguards w Walkie-Talkies strapped to their trunks and loud-hailers arm's reach. Bored, two of the hot dogs train their binoc on some local color.

A TV Mobile Unit Van is setting up: cables snaking to cam a camera with a big sports zoom sitting on the platform a the truck, a spiffy announcer-type in a blazer with his  station's call letters on the pocket. Inside the darkened control room, we can see the pale blue squares of monitor in a mosaic against one wall, facing the switcher.

Hooper is methodically patrolling in his boat. Tactically flanking a three-hundred-yard apron of black repellent ar four small watch-boats. A tiny pleasure boat darts around the repellent line. Farther out, crossing back and forth, are patrol boats. To top it all off, a Coast Guard helico hovers and patrols three hundred feet above.

At least eight monitors, reflecting the outputs of three  cameras and two tape machines, as well as line, preview, effects monitors. MONITOR: CAMERA 1: Holding on a group of happy citizen-ba as they unpack their gear, wave to camera, run into the w MONITOR: CAMERA 2: The Repellent Line, set in place by Co Guardsmen in small boats, setting out floats, dumping  repellent into the ocean. MONITOR: CAMERA 3: Close on the Bandstand, where Amity's  band is playing lilting patriotic airs. After we've seen this activity, we can take a look at wha going on: the preparation of the tape segment for the six o'clock news.
Put 1 on the line. In five. 4. 3. 2.  1. Roll.
On the "Tape 1" and "Line" monitors, we see Vaughn being  interviewed by the Announcer in the blazer.
...and with me is the Mayor of Amity,  Lawrence Vaughn. Mr. Vaughn, how  about those rumors?

How about them indeed. I'm pleased  and happy to repeat the news that we  have, in fact, caught and killed a  large predator that supposedly injured  some bathers here. As you can see,  it's a beautiful day, the beaches  are open, and the folks here are  having a wonderful time. Amity,  y'know, means 'Friendship.'

MONITOR: CAMERA 1: As Vaughn speaks to us on the monitors the monitor for Camera 1 pans over to show a Sightseeing pull up in the parking area, and a horde of media vulture spilling out, carrying cameras with long lenses and tripo telescopes, sunshades and parasols, all the equipment of curious and none of the equipment of the holiday bather o swimmer.
