TAPE 1 AND LINE MONITORS: Close on the Announcer, Vaughn of the picture.
Also here today is a Marine Biologist  and Research Fellow from the  Oceanographic Institute, Matthew  Hooper. Mr. Hooper, what've you heard?

What I've heard and what I've seen  are two different things. I believe  there is a large Great White Shark --  Carcharodon Cacharias - in the waters  off this very beach, that he has  killed and that he will kill again...
Hooper's voice fades off as someone at the mixer panel di his mike off, and brings up the Announcer's lavalier.
(moving into center  frame) And there you have it -- two different  opinions, by men of good will. The  holiday crowd here at Amity seems to  be making up its own mind...

The camera pans off him to a happy family headed for the  beach. MONITOR: CAMERA 3: Zooms in on the puffing face of the tu player. MONITOR: CAMERA 2: Brody and the Announcer. MONITOR: TAPE 1 and LINE: Back on the Announcer, his lips moving, but his sound turned off. We hear, instead, the s from Monitor Camera 2, Brody and the same Announcer.
I'm sorry, I just don't have the  time.
Recue the machines. 2, pan off the  Chief and show me some tits and ass.  1, get me some cute kids. 3... see  if you got a shot at the water.
MONITORS: CAMERAS 1, 2 and 3: The cameras seek out the  appropriate activity as the Director calls for it.
(holds up stopwatch) Mayor, 43 seconds, Biologist 45  seconds. That's equal time, right?
Right. (he presses "Talkback"  button to his  announcer) Jerry, come on in and look at this. (to his headset) Roll 2. In five, 4. 3. 2. 1.
Starts showing us the assembled interview segment we've j seen, starting with the Announcer's opening remarks.
Amity Island is famed for its clear  air and white sand beaches. But a  cloud appeared...
His voice is dialed under as the Announcer himself appear in the control room to watch himself on the monitors.
Look at that shine on my nose. It's  a beacon.
Close enough for remote.
As Vaughn begins his spiel again, the other monitors show the action on the beach.
...I'm pleased and happy...
Think we ought to stick around?
What else you got?
Teachers' strike downtown.
Christenson, this is Al. Union says  time for Engineering Five.
That's five minutes, guys. Coffee.

Vaughn is in his shirtsleeves, having slipped out of his  jacket. He mops his brow, and surveys the beachfront. At this mom there's nobody swimming. He approaches a familiar Selectm nods hello, and squats beside him on the sand.
Why don't you get in the water?
I don't want to wash off my suntan  lotion. I'll get a burn...
(some urgency) Nobody's going in!
On an adjoining blanket, a spirited Ruth Gordon type is  sitting, watching brightly as her manservant, a polished  Eric Harrison type, prepares some tea from a thermos.
Is there nobody going in? What a  shame. Arthur, should I be going in?
(pouring tea) If you'd like.
He puts down the tea service, and leads her towards the w At the edge of the sea, she stops, and he walks in.
(as he enters the  waves) It's very nice. Not too cold... Quite  refreshing... Very pleasant....
He ducks his head under for a final look around. His drip head rises triumphantly from the surf.
No sharks, m'lady.
She starts into the water, he takes her parasol, escortin her the rest of the way into the ocean.
This is marvelous! Arthur, I want to  come back to this very spot. Will  you make a note of where we are?

Encouraged by the sight of the Woman and Arthur, and Vaug quiet urgings, people begin to wander into the surf, a fe at first, and then a rush, as people plunge in and begin  enjoying the pleasures of ocean bathing. The Selectman go in, his family follows, Vaughn watches it all, beaming.
Hendricks is on the radio while a Coast Guard spotter wor the sonar.
Anything? Thought I saw a shadow.  Over.
Pan to the water.
As before, 400 pairs of enticing, yummy swimmers' legs,  kicking like animated hors d'oeuvres.
A breathtaking view. The copter spotter looks down with n eye and binoculars.
Nothing from up here, Daisy. Over.
(into walkie-talkie) False alarm. Must be this glare.
He is walking down the beach, threading his way through t happy hordes. Meadows nods "hello."
Who's scared to go in! I was in! Up  to your knees, yeah -- So come with  me -- I'll go again.
Beautiful day, Chief!
A group of youngsters playing with Michael Brody's dinghy They are hauling it toward the surf.
Hey Mikey -- !
Michael turns as Brody trots toward him.
You're not going to the ocean with  that, are you son?
I'm all checked out for light surf  and look at it.
Do me this favor just once. Use the  ponds.
Dad, the ponds are for old ladies.
Just a favor for your old man.
(confused) Sure, Dad.
TV cameramen are packing up their gear. For them it's a w
Suddenly his Walkie-Talkie fizzes, and the Copter Spotter voice overloads the speaker.
Copter to Daisy! Red Four, Red Four!
Guns are up, heads turning everywhere.
(into walkie-talkie) Where -- ?
Went under your -- There!
The Coast Guard sonar operator spots it and pales. A slic black dorsal fin is slicing a wake toward the swimming ar
Jesus Christ -- Shark!
Rigid and choked, he almost breaks the "send" button tryi to transmit.
Everybody out! Out of the water,  please -- leave the water, please --
A lifeguard in a loft behind him begins blowing on his  whistle.
shouting hysterically.
No whistles! No whistles!

Dozens of bathers halfway out of the water, turn to see.  More whistles, and they start toward shore. We hear panic voices ad-libbing; "Shark," "Look Out," etc. The loudhail sounding more urgent now, and a contagious dread seizes o person after another. Entire groups of people begin pulli toward shore, some of them obviously trying to control a  growing hysteria in others.
are converging, heading toward the repellent line as if  tracking an underwater shadow. The fin is beyond the repe cordons and heading into the crowds.
Caught on the other end of the line, he is wheeling in a  broad, hot-dogger's circle turn, headed back.

People begin screaming. Kids are suddenly separated from  their parents. Others seem to forget how to swim. One myo little girl has her glasses bumped off and she begins to in blinded panic. Ellen Brody looks around frantic.
The riflemen in the boats are trying to get a bead, but t many civilians create a hazard. The Coast Guardsmen attem to sever the repellent cord to gain access to the bathing area and the heaving fin.

This is a confirmation of our worst dread -- a full-blown headlong water panic. Screaming vacationers claw their wa over the bodies of the less able. Some literally attempt walk over the bobbing heads and glistening backs of other pulling for dry land.

Horrified faces. Some are stunned and wandering in slow,  tentative circles, while others are helped out by friends Five people try to mount a rubber raft. Ugly reminders that each of us is Number One. Brody enters shot, yelling into his walkie-talkie, someon charges past him to help an old man out of the water.
Dragging the helpless from the surf. Tears well in Brody' eyes. The screaming is deafening. The TV unit is hopping and down in rage and frustration.
Why did we wrap? Get that! Somebody  get that!

One thousand survivors pack the beach, standing absolutel still. A numbing cold sets in, and people shiver against  each other. Muted sobs, whimpering, coughing. The six burly lifeguards huddle together like Cub Scouts.

The monstrous black fin turns a slow circle as two Coast  Guardsmen manage to cut their own repellent line. All boa converge on the dynamic fin. Men raise their guns to fire Others adlib nautical commands in a uniquely calculated  fashion.

It slips sideways, revealing for the first time a tiny bl snorkel. Then appears the faces of two youngsters whom we will recall from the coven behind the dune. The fin bobs  back, a beaverboard replica attached to a partially subme surfboard. One youngster looks up and is greeted by:
Twenty rifles and shotguns pointed directly at him.  Surrounding him on three sides. Some of the policemen sta to lower their guns -- struck dumb.
He throttles back suddenly, subsiding into his own wake, eyes still restlessly searching.
his only defense, he begins to cry -- and feebly raises h hands in unconditional surrender.
The narrow estuary leading into the half-mile is rough to Two children digging in the sand and unaware of the beach panic one hundred yards away look up, and the little girl points.
is cruising through the narrows and toward the busy pond.
He sees it, and jams his throttle forward. He steers with one hand, fumbling urgently for his walkie-talkie with th other.
The circle of boats around the little pranksters, the cro huddled on the beach, Hooper's boat suddenly arrowing tow the estuary, leaving a huge boiling wake.

He catches Hooper's boat out of the corner of his eye.  Curious, he follows its progress. It's urgency finally  communicates itself to Vaughn, who begins a shambling tro across the dunes towards a rise overlooking the estuary.
Vaughn gets there just in time to see the disaster. He  watches, helpless, trying to shout, out of breath. Stunne

Michael is tacking full-sail in his boat with a friend, K Kit is admiring the shark's tooth necklace around his own neck while Michael rubs some water on the scratches left it. The fin, huge, black and real, crosses behind them. They not yet aware. The fin seems to circle and return. It hea toward Michael's boat when another small dinghy gets in i way -- a weekend novice just finishing a thermos of coffe when he is "bumped." The entire boat is overturned. Micha sees the fin now as it collides with him, the entire bow  lifting out of the water and rolling over on the port sid Michael and Kit are thrown head first. Three heads in the water come up sputtering, the fin betw them crossing back. Michael freezes. The fin comes direct at him, growing into the sky, passing him so close he cou touch it, but ignoring him as it follows the flailing and panicked weekend novice. Catches him. Michael watches. Th all too familiar explosion of water -- a choked off screa the head and upper torso of the novice passing Michael sw as though being carried off -- a current of blood trailin behind.
(passing a horrified  Michael, who half  extends one hand, as  if to help) It's no good. I'm dead... (and he is)
A renewed cry of shark!
He turns. Oh God! Running through the slogging sand.
A sudden turn. She runs.
He's got the walkie-talkie to his mouth.
Block the estuary! The estuary!

Three boats racing to carry out the orders. The black fin passing the two children, racing to get out. Hooper reach the mouth before the others. The fin won't veer off. It s into the little vessel, bumping it aside. The fin is left racing into open water. Blood leavings. Hooper leaping ov the side, slogging towards Michael.
Copter roars in buzzing the shark, but too late.
They are pulling Michael out of the water as Hooper splas up. Michael is conscious but in shock -- his eyes staring nothing.
(feeling his face) He's in shock. Get blankets!
People gather and Brody snatches beach towels out of thei hands. They cover Michael and carry him off the beach, fe raised above his head.
Michael is wheeled out in the bed. Brody and Ellen are th Sean is sleepy in Brody's arms. Vaughn is waiting in the  hall.
The doctor said it's okay -- mild  shock. He can come home in the  morning.
(to Michael) Hey, big guy -- you want anything  from home?
My cars. And a comic book.
(sees Vaughn) Here -- (gives baby to Ellen) Take him home.
Home... New York?
No. Home here.
Ellen exits.
(crossing to Vaughn) Got a pen on you?
Why?
There's only one thing you're good  for anymore -- signing a damn voucher.  Here. It's an authorization to employ  a contractor.
I don't know if I can do that without  a...
(interrupting) I'm going to hire Quint to kill the  fish. I want to see that shark dead.
Maybe we can save August...
Forget it. This summer's had it. Next summer's had it. You're the  mayor of Shark City. You wanted to  keep the beaches open. What happens  when the town finds out about that?
I was acting in the town's best  interests...
The best interest in this town would  be to see that fish belly-up in the  water with a hole in his head. You  do the right thing. You authorize  me. (indicates paper) Right there. Whatever it costs.
My kids were on that beach...
Just sign it, Larry.
Vaughn signs, and Brody takes the paper and exits.

Brody and Hooper are approaching Quint's house. They ente through the big wooden doors, into another circle of Hell Smoke and steam from two big oil drums sitting over fires fills the air. Quint and his mate, Herschel, are grinding pieces of pilot whale into chum. The whale lies bloody on the floor, its ruined carcass adding to the stench of oth sharks being boiled in the drums, their tails suspended i the air. Diesel fumes and decay fill the air, and tools, ropes, br bits of iron and engine parts litter the floor. Wall hang of rope and floats, and buoys, barrels, tackle and gear a conspire to frame the killing floor. Brody and Hooper navigate the obstacle course.
This has got to be one big  violation...
(handling some gear) This is quite a place.
Keep your hands off my stuff.
He emerges from the steam and smoke.
Did you bring a check?
What?
Cash? Or do we do this on a handshake  and a promise?
I'm authorized by the township of  Amity to hire you as an independent  contractor. We'll meet your price.  $10,000.
And my regular daily rate -- $200,  whether we catch him or not.
You got it.
And incidental damages, if any...
You got it.
And you get the Mayor off my back  with this zoning crap. Nobody tells  me how to run my property.
You got it.
And, uh, a case of apricot brandy  and you buy the lunch.
Two cases. And dinner when you land.
(pours drink) Try some of this. I made it myself.
Brody tastes.
Here's to swimmin' with bowlegged  women.
Herschel interrupts. He's stopped working, and is wiping hands on a bloody rag.
Mr. Quint...
Quint wheels to face him.
I'm not goin'. No sir.
You want to get paid, you go.
Forget the money. You can't pay me  enough. I ain't crazy. I worked some  big mean fish with you, but I ain't  goin' on this one.

This is the last time I hear from  you. I don't want anyone with piss  for blood on my vessel. Put that  blackfish on board, pump the bilges,  and top off the fuel tanks, and finish  up in the morning. Then you're on  the beach.
You're going to need an extra hand...
Quint turns to see this new voice, and starts walking tow him.
This is Matt Hooper...
I know who he is...
He's from the Oceanographic Institute.
I've been to sea since I was 12.  I've crewed three Trans-pacs --
Transplants?
-- and an America's Cup Trials...
I'm not talking about day sailing or  pleasure boating. I'm talking about  working for a living. Sharking.
And I'm not talking about hooking  some poor dogfish or sand shark. I'm  talking about a Great White.
Are you now. I know about porkers in  the water -- (throws him some rope) Here. Tie me a sheepshank.
Hooper ties the knot effortlessly.
I don't need to pass basic seamanship.
Let me see your hands...
He takes Hooper's hands in his own big bloody fists, and  feels them as he talks.

Ha. City hands. You been counting  money. If you had a $5000 net and  $2000 worth of fish in it, and along  comes Mr. White, and makes it look  like a kiddy scissors class has gone  to work on it and made paper dolls.  If you'd ever worked for a living,  you'd know what that means.
Look, I don't need to hear any of  this working class hero crap. Some  party boat skipper who's killed a  few sharks...
(interrupting) Hey. Knock it off. I don't want to  have to listen to this while we're  out there...
What do you mean 'We...?'
It's my charter. My party.
All right, Commissioner. But when  we're on my ship, I am Master, Mate  and Pilot. And I want him... (indicates Hooper) ...along for ballast.
You got it.
The Mate is loading. He hands Quint the items on his chec list as Quint takes them aboard.
5 lengths of 1/2-inch, 20 number  14's, straight gaff, flying gaffs,  tail rope, eye splice, M-1, 20 clips,  pliers, irons...

As he talks, we see Hooper coming down to the dock. Wheel a wagon behind him are two long-haired Research Assistant from the Institute. On the wagon, among other things, is big shark cage. At dockside, Hooper checks his list, as h signs for his issue.
Powerhead, CO2 darts, hypo, regulator,  tanks, depth gauge, camera, extra  magazines, cage...
You got everything you asked for?
All of it. And thank Dr. Miro for  me. And tell Borack I'll catch up  with them in New Zealand.
This is actually a killing expedition?
An eye for an eye, you know.
Hey, Squirt! You want to stow this  gear or you want me to use it for  ballast? It ain't good for much but  bait.
(to Assistant) I'll see ya. Tell Dorothy hello.
Hooper sees his gear approaching.
Quint sees Hooper approaching with the large cage.

Hello, Junior. What are you? Some  kind of half-assed astronaut? (to himself) Jesus Christ, when I was a kid, every  little squirt wanted to be a harpooner  or a sword fisherman. What d'ya have  there -- a portable shower?
Anti-Shark cage.
Who's inside, you or the shark?
Hooper indicates "me."
You're in the cage? (Hooper nods) The cage is in the water? (Hooper nods) The shark is in the water too? (Hooper nods) You're in the water with the shark.
Hooper nods. Quint sings "Spanish Ladies" half to himself
Comin' aboard...
She's carrying a little plastic shopping bag, he's wearin shiny new foul weather gear, bundled up, sweaty,  uncomfortable. She gives him as good a hug as she can manage under the  circumstances.
Did you take your dramamine? (Brody nods) Here.
She straightens his coat, and gives him a shaving kit to  carry aboard with his toiletries. From the deck, Quint  whistles derisively.
Hurry up, Chief, daylight's a wastin'.
Is that him?
(to Ellen) Colorful, isn't he?
You going to be all right?
Nothing to worry about -- I'll survive  this.
I'll see you back soon. There's an  extra pair of glasses in your black  socks, and there's some suntan lotion  and blistex in your kit.
Brody nods, and holds her hand for a wordless moment.
(sings) 'Here is the body of Mary Lee. For  15 years she kept her virginity. Not  a bad record for this vicinity.'
There is a sputter and roar as the Orca's diesels kick on
Yo-ho-ho and a bottle of rum.
(hugging him) What'll I tell the kids?
Tell 'em I went fishin'!
They laugh together, and exchange a short, fierce kiss.
Cast off the bow line! Now your stern!
Its diesels chugging, the Orca pulls away from the pier. Ellen has already resolutely turned her back on it, and i walking off the dock back onto dry land.
Quint has set a course out towards the open sea. He lashe the wheel, and jumps down to address Hooper and Brody, wh are standing together in the stern.

(to Brody) Front-Bow, Back-Stern, Port,  Starboard. Aloft, Below. It's not a  staircase, it's a ladder, it's not a  rope, it's a line, and if you don't  get it right... (indicates porthole) I'll throw your ass through that  little round window.
He laughs at his joke. This is probably something he tell all his charters.

Now hear this. You're aboard the  fishing vessel 'Orca,' and I'm her  Captain, Master, Mate, and Owner.  You'll jump when I holler. We're  doin' a job here, and Christ, I ain't  got time to watch you birds get hooks  in your ass and fall overboard. Ship  with me, and you'll do all right.  Cross me, and I'll slap you upside  your heads. Now -- if you boys are  ready -- let's go fishin'.
He starts moving gear around, preparing chum barrels, set hooks, Hooper gives him a hand, Brody stays out of the wa

It is quiet as the Orca drifts along in the current, a wi chum slick spreading behind it. A couple of flag buoys sp along our perspective show us the miles the boat has gone Quint spots something in the water -- a small blue shark  attracted by the chum. He rigs a small pole with a piece bait, and throws it over the side.
Here's something for you...
The shark takes the bait, Quint brutally and efficiently  sets the hook, and reels the shark alongside. He hauls it part way out of the water, and sticks it with a gaff. Hoo and Brody watch.
Tailrope dropping on him. Gaffed and bleeding, the shark immobilized by Quint's practiced hands. He takes one of h big knives and poses for a moment beside the struggling f
These greedy sons-a-bitches will eat  their own guts.
He slices into the shark's underbelly. We hear the sound entrails plopping into the water. Brody is almost retchin and Hooper is just displeased.
The gutted shark swimming in circles biting at its own  entrails.
Fins closing in on the wounded shark.
Go ahead, you cannibals. Tell 'em  where you got it!

A boil of water and the flash of fins and teeth as the lo sharks erupt in a feeding frenzy, jaws snapping, blood  spewing, a sudden display of the fury and blind predatory drive of the fearsome species.
What's that supposed to prove?
Just a little appetizer. I want our  porker to know we're serving. I want  to put some iron into that big yap...

head_text.subj: HOOPER AND BRODY REACT AS WE

text: The Orca is drifting in neutral. The ocean is like gelati the sun sucking heat waves from its surface. Brody at the stern, handkerchief on his head to protect from further  sunburn, has been handed the slimiest job on a shark hunt the ladling out of chum. There are several empty chum bar A flag buoy bobs in the wake of the boat, another waits t be tossed over the side. Brody is reeling with nausea. He opens his overnight kit and takes out a handkerchief and  some Old Spice after-shave. He pours the after-shave into the cloth, presses it to his nose. Hooper is also in the  stern.
Keep that chum line going -- we've  got five good miles. Don't break it.
Who's driving the boat?
Nobody. We're drifting with the  current.
(using the fish finder) Nothing. Nothing, nothing, nothing.

(to Hooper) Hell, in the old days we went out  with good charts, good sounding lead,  and a damn good compass. Nowadays,  these kids are afraid to go out  without depth finders, radar, radio,  electric toothbrush, every stupid  thing...

Quint opens a can of beer and drains it in one long pull, crushing the empty and throwing it over the side. Hooper  drains his coffee from a styrofoam cup, and cracks it in hand with a silly "plup." He stows the pieces in an empty chum barrel.
(to Brody) Get a fresh barrel.

Brody goes to unlash a fresh barrel, but can't figure out the knots. He finally tugs on a piece of rope, and it all comes loose... barrel, shark cage, and, most important,  Hooper's tanks, clattering and rolling on the deck.
(jumping up) Watch it! Compressed air -- you screw  around with one of those and Boom!  Careful, huh?

(mutters) Real fine stuff but it won't mean a  thing to Mr. Whitey, of course... he  didn't go to schools in electronics.  He was born with what he does best.  Eat. He's a swimming appetite. 'Course  he might eat this stuff, but then  I've seen him eat a rocking chair,  too. (to Brody) Next time, ask me.

The men are in different positions on the boat. Hooper on the flying bridge. Quint in the stern, Brody hanging over the rail, puking. Quint takes a wide red strip of whale meat and a gnarled  squid from the garbage pail, and searches for a No. 2 hoo rig. He holds up a strip of whale.
(eyeing bait) That's pilot whale, isn't it?
It ain't a Big Mac. (to Brody) The expert don't approve. What do  you thing? You're closer to the  situation. (laughs)
Brody shades his eyes from the white sun as Quint baits u
(croaky) Why are we way out here, when the  shark's back there?
(snapping bait to his  leader) ...'cause this is where he lives.  You gotta think like they do.
(to himself) Easy for you -- they got a brain the  size of a radish.
Quint sits in the fighting chair. He casts off, murmuring the line feeds out.
(to Brody) Now if he weren't around, we'd of  hooked something else by now, wouldn't  we? But he scared 'em all away. Big  lonesome son of a bitch...

Quint at ease in his chair, Brody near him, practicing ty knots. The line starts to move, a few feet at a time; bot men watch. Then the line whizzes off the reel. Brody jump up. Hooper springs to the deck. Quint puts his hand on th drag and addresses the situation softly.
-- he'll gulp it down now... (making gulping noises) Hooooooo!
Quint tightens drag and strikes. The line goes whizzing o Brody runs to Quint's side. Hooper springs up to the flyi bridge.
You got it?
(turning with the  pull) Get behind me, dummy! (shouts to Hooper) Reverse her and turn -- he's taking  too much line! (to Brody) Wet my reel, quick!
Brody goes to get water, the boat surges, he staggers. Br pours water on the screaming reel, nearly unspooled now. Hooper is turning the boat around and the line changes  direction.
(straining, muscles  popping) Starboard, for Chris'sake --
Hooper steers it sharply.
(to Hooper) Hey, you! Farmer! Half-speed there...
(almost to himself) Aye, Aye SIR. Stand by to repel  boarders. Poop the mainsail. Argh,  Jim Boy.
Again the line changes direction, down this time.
(to Hooper) Neutral! (to himself) Where the hell is he going?
Quint reeling in like mad.
Oh, this ain't foolin' me -- (rod arcs down with a  surge) Sure -- try it!
He ad libs brief instructions to Brody as the line rushes out and there is less tension. Quint is horsing up and do reeling in.
Makin' believe it's easy now.
The line is almost vertical, and Quint shows a hint of  bafflement. He reels in suspiciously.
Gettin' ready to run again -- no?  No? (suspicious) What's he playin' here? (reels in furiously,  to Brody) Put the gloves on! (to fish) Let's see who's gonna tease who now!
Let it go, don't waste your time.
(to Hooper) Down here, Hooper!
Hooper is rushing down.
I don't know what it is, but it's  not a shark.

(bathed in sweat;  hauling, reeling) Look -- you may be a big Yahoo in  the lab, but out here you're just  supercargo, and you'll do as I say,  or you can take your gear and  backstroke home. Now get down here!
The leaders show above the water line. Brody is wide-eyed waiting for that first look.
The wire's showing!
(to Brody) Unbuckle me -- fast! (to Hooper) Grab the leader. He ain't normal,  this one... they never --
It's too wild, too erratic. It's a  marlin or a stingray. It's a gamefish.
Hooper snaps the rope onto the leader and holds on.
Watch your hands -- (suddenly to Brody) Grab onto this!

Before he realizes what's happening, Brody is clumsily  clutching at the big rod, appalled. Quint skips away for flying gaff. He picks one, turns... That's when the leader lashes free, sending Hooper crashi backward in a serious fall, and the rod whips at Brody's  forehead, drawing blood. Quint snatches up the rod and re in. The wires have been bitten through.
(to Hooper) A marlin, or a stingray. Huh. Don't  ever tell me my business again. Get  back up on the bridge.
(stunned) I'm okay...
(to Brody) Fasten the pole.
What's the point with hooks and Lines? --
Don't tell me my business! (to Hooper, points) Quarter-mile, that way. Full throttle.
Hooper shakes off his dizziness and obeys. Brody watches  Quint rig up a new leader, hook up the same bait.
(nursing forehead,  gesturing at rod and  reel) How -- if they're gonna keep on  breaking?
What I do is trick him to the surface,  got that? Then I can jab him,  understand? (goes to flybridge,  muttering) Think I'm gonna haul it in as if  he's a catfish, like everyone else  does?
Brody goes inside to inspect his forehead.
(suddenly, pointing) Over there!
What do you see?
(still looking) At least you handle the boat all  right. Stop. Here... Cut the engine.

Hooper cuts the engines as Quint swings nimbly down. He s stock still on the main deck, motioning Brody to be silen Then picking up the newly rigged rod, Quint softshoes it  over to the chair. About to sit down, he freezes.
looking hard at something.
staring, eyes widening.
moving in, surprised, interested, fascinated.
We see the shark. First the fin... then the head and uppe jaws, ten or twenty yards off the side of the boat. It fi submerges, its tail giving a final slap.
He puts his rod away and stares at it. And stares. And st Hooper is the first to break the silence.
20 feet, if it's an inch...
25 feet. And three tons of him there.
Hooper is nearly beside himself with a strange ecstasy. H leaps toward his gear.
(quietly, to Brody) I never saw one that big.
What do we do? Get some help? Radio  in?
Quint ignores him and moves off into the pilot house, whe he swiftly takes out his green case, and opens it to begi to assemble something inside it. Brody is alone on the de with Hooper.
How're we gonna handle this?

Hooper is contained in his own excitement. He has finally come up with what he was looking for -- an expensive Niko through which he peers intently at the shark alongside. H is talking half to himself as he fine-tunes the range fin and focus. He is squeaking and bubbling in an unsuppressed emotional boil.

(very, very high) There's a formula! Girth, about 150  inches, squared, divide by 800 --  son of a bitch, they are not going  to believe this! -- divide by 2000...  three tons! (after Quint) You're right, you old fart! Three  tons! (ad libs ecstasy)

He is assembling the Greener harpoon gun, deftly screwing the long wooden stock, the heavy steel barrel, and big sh with the wicked barbs, the frame all rigged with line. Pa him, on the deck, we can still see Hooper. As Quint is wo with the gun, the radio suddenly squawks into life.
Amity Point Light Station to Orca.  This is Amity Point Light Station,  to Orca...
Quint snaps the mouthpiece to his lips.
Orca here.
I have Mrs. Martin Brody here...
Put her on.
...push this? Oh. It's working. Hello,  Martin?
This is Quint, Missus.
I just wanted to know if you were  all right... the Coast Guard let me  use their radio. Is Chief Brody there?
He's busy.
Well... is everything all right?
Just fine, Missus. We'll be back  soon. Everything's fine. We haven't  seen anything yet. Orca out.
He snaps off the radio, and, for good measure, pulls the  plug from the power source.
The big shark is slicing through the water just below the surface, its fin high, the big gray back glistening, the  teeth gleaming.
(on deck) Damn it! I need something in the  foreground to give it some scale.  Martin! Stand here! No, to your left!

He is positioning Martin frantically, trying to include B the shark, and the Orca in the same frame. Quint finishes with the gun, and as a final gesture, snaps an explosive  cartridge into the breech. He empties the box of cartridg onto the table, snatches up a big handful, and drops them into a pocket, and heads out on deck, bound for the bow  pulpit.
Quint appears with the harpoon gun. He throws one end of line to Hooper.
Here. Rig this to the forward keg up  there.
He indicates the barrels on the foredeck.
(to Brody) Get up there and steer her. Follow  my hand, and hold 'er steady. I've  got to get a clean shot at that  porker's head.

Quint moves up toward the bow, Brody goes up to the flyin bridge to take the wheel, Hooper starts for the foredeck, but stops to rummage in his kit, throwing gear around as desperately hunts for something.
Hurry up, rig the line!

He finds what he's looking for. A small, powerful strobe  unit, waterproofed, a miniature signal beacon. He trigger it, and it begins to pulse with a light we can see even i the sun. Hooper scampers to the foredeck and begins to rig the lig to the first barrel, as the shark begins to surface near bow.
(to Brody) Come to port. Watch my hand. Steady  now...
He guides Brody with hand signals. Brody tries urgently t get it right, not to oversteer, to try to hold the big bo with its throbbing diesels on the course that Quint is  indicating.
The line, man, the line!
Hooper is rigging like crazy.
Brody steering f.g., Hooper on the foredeck with the barr Quint leaning out over the pulpit, the gun at the ready, shark crossing inexorably in front of them.
Agonizing over his shot as the shark approaches, glancing back to see if the line is properly rigged and Hooper is  clear of it.
Get clear, damn you!
The shark is in position, Hooper shouts, a moment too lat
Clear!
Quint fires. The harpoon slams into the shark behind his  head, half-way along the back in front of the big dorsal  fin.
Jesus H. Christ On a Crutch!

The rope snaps out in a blur of violent motion, Hooper ju back, and the barrel leaps out of its rack, pulled by the line rigged to the harpoon. It bounds forward and into th sea, past Quint, who is already reloading, mounting anoth steel shaft. In the distance, the barrel bobs and skips  violently in the water, dragged by the shark in his merci moves.
Now you've done it, you piss-ant.  Stop and rig a goddam tinker toy to  my gear. Let the bastard fight the  keg for a while. He can't stay down  with that on.
Hooper, furious with himself, runs for the flying bridge take the helm from Brody.

head_text.subj: THE FLYING BRIDGE, BRODY AND HOOPER

text: Hooper has snatched the wheel, and is ramming the throttl forward as he spins the wheel in a frantic 180 degree tur
(to Quint) Rig another keg! I'm bringing her  around!
His eyes dart about the ocean, looking for the barrel, as hot-dogs the ship around in a violent expression of his o disgust with himself.
(to himself) God damn it! We had him! (to Quint) I'm coming about!

He spins the wheel again, trying to make the big boat han like a formula speedster. The decks tip and the rigging s under the sudden strain. Brody is caught unaware, and tum off his feet, sliding across the deck to fetch up against wall. the M1 Rifle is close to his hand. He stares at it.

Hooper is anguished, intense, trying to find the shark,  spinning the wheel, compounding his error, tipping the bo in rolling turns as he crosses his own wake. Quint has tu his back to the sea, and is in the pulpit looking up at  Hooper, staring at him, excluding everything else. As Quint folds his arms and stares at Hooper, we realize sun is going down, and it's getting dark.
Why don't we go in? Get another crack  at him tomorrow.
We got a barrel on him. We can't  lose him. We stay out here until we  find him.
Hooper throttles back, and the roar of the diesels subsid and the boat resumes an even keel, slowly circling the oc
Let's call in -- we can radio and  have a big boat here in an hour...
(grim) You hired me, remember? It's my  $10,000. It's my shark...

Throttled back to slow ahead, the boat circles the water  endlessly, staying over the shark like an avenging angel. Its running lights gleam in the night, and a glow lights interior of the pilot house. A bright strobe glints on th water winking once like a firefly.
Brody and Hooper at the table, Quint at the wheel, keepin his eye on the light.
He's up again.

He corrects course slightly to keep the barrel buoy in si Hooper is sitting at the table, morose. Brody is staring a couple of open cans of beans or beef stew, or some othe crappy rations Quint has on board. Dirty spoons stuck in open cans show us this has not been a formal dinner. Quin fumbles on the chart shelf and produces some of his home  brew. He takes a pull, and hands it to Hooper, who takes a doub Brody touches the fresh abrasion on his forehead, where t fishing rod caught him. Quint bends forward and pulls his hair aside to show some near the crown.
That's not so bad. Look at this:  ...St. Paddy's Day in Knocko Nolans,  in Boston, where some sunovabitch  winged me upside the head with a  spittoon.
Brody looks politely. Hooper stirs himself.
Look here. (extends a forearm) Steve Kaplan bit me during recess.
Quint is amused. He presents his own formidable forearm.
Wire burn. Trying to stop a backstay  from taking my head off.
(rolling up a sleeve) Moray Eel. Bit right through a wet  suit.
Brody is fascinated. Quint and Hooper take a long pull fr the bottle.

Face and head scars come from amateur  amusements in the bar room. This  love line here... (he bends an ear  forward) ...that's from some crazy Frenchie  come after me with a knife. I caught  him with a good right hand right in  the snot locker and laid him amongst  the sweetpeas.
Ever see one like this?
He hauls up his pants leg, revealing a wicked white scar.
Bull shark scraped me while I was  taking samples...
Nothing! A pleasure scar. Look here --
He starts rolling up his own dirty pants leg.
Slammed with a thresher's tail. Look  just like somebody caressed me with  a nutmeg grater...
Brody is drawn into their boasting comparisons. He secret checks his own appendix scar, decides not to enter the  contest.
I'll drink to your leg.
And I'll drink to yours.
They toast each other. Brody looks around, sees the strob blink once through the darkened window.
Wait a minute, young fella. Look.  Just look. Don't touch...
He starts lowering his pants to reveal a place on one hip where the tissue is scarred and irregular.
...Mako. Fell out of the tail rope  and onto the deck. You don't get  bitten by one of those bastards but  twice -- your first and your last.
(considerably drunker) I think I can top that, Mister...
Hooper is pulling at his shirt, trying to get it off, but it's tangling its sleeves, and won't come undone.
Gimme a hand, here. I got something  to show you --
Brody lends a hand. The shirt slips part way off.
(indicating his chest) There. Right there. Mary Ellen Moffit  broke my heart. Let's drink to Mary  Ellen.
The two men raise their mugs in a toast.
And here's to the ladies. And here's  to their sisters; I'd rather one  Miss than a shipload of Misters.
He drinks, Hooper follows.
(shows belly) Look a' that -- Bayonet Iwo Jima.
(aside) C'mon. Middle appendix --
(aside) I almost had 'im.
Brody is looking at a small white patch on Quint's other  forearm.
(pointing) What's that one, there?
(changing) Tattoo. Had it taken off.
Don't tell me -- 'Death Before  Dishonor.' 'Mother.' 'Semper Fi.'  Uhhh... 'Don't Tread on Me.' C'mon --  what?
'U.S.S Indianapolis.' 1944.
What's that, a ship?
(incredulous) You were on the Indianapolis? In  '45? Jesus...
Quint remembering.

Yeah. The U.S.S. Indianapolis. June 29th, 1945, three and a half  minutes past midnight, two torpedoes  from a Japanese submarine slammed  into our side. Two or three. We was  still under sealed orders after  deliverin' the bomb...the Hiroshima  bomb...we was goin' back across the  Pacific from Tinian to Leyte. Damn  near eleven hundred men went over  the side. The life boats was lashed  down so tight to make the bomb run  we couldn't cut a single one adrift.  Not one. And there was no rafts.  None. That vessel sank in twelve  minutes. Yes, that's all she took.  We didn't see the first shark till  we'd been in the water about an hour.  A thirteen-footer near enough. A  blue. You measure that by judgin'  the dorsal to the tail. What we didn't  know... of course the Captain knew...I  guess some officers knew... was the  bomb mission had been so secret, no  distress signals was sent. What the  men didn't know was that they wouldn't  even list us as overdue for a week.  Well, I didn't know that -- I wasn't  an officer -- just as well perhaps.  So some of us were dead already --  in the water -- just hangin' limp in  our lifejackets. And several already  bleedin'. And the three hundred or  so laying on the bottom of the ocean.  As the light went, the sharks came  crusin'. We formed tight groups --  somewhat like squares in an old battle --  You know what I mean -- so that when  one come close, the man nearest would  yell and shout and pound the water  and sometimes it worked and the fish  turned away, but other times that  shark would seem to look right at a  man -- right into his eyes -- and in  spite of all shoutin' and poundin'  you'd hear that terrible high  screamin' and the ocean would go  red, then churn up as they ripped  him.  Then we'd reform our little  squares. By the first dawn the sharks  had taken more than a hundred. Hard  for me to count but more than a  hundred. I don't know how many sharks.  Maybe a thousand. I do know they  averaged six men an hour. All kinds --  blues, makos, tigers. All kinds. (Pause) In the middle of the second day,  some of us started to go crazy from  the thirst. One fella cried out he  saw a river, another claimed he saw  a waterfall, some started to drink  the ocean and choked on it, and some  left our little groups -- our little  squares -- and swam off alone lookin'  for islands and the sharks always  took them right away. It was mainly  the young fellas that did that --  the older ones stayed where they  was. That second day -- my life jacket  rubbed me raw and that was more blood  in the water. Oh my. On Thursday  morning I bumped up against a friend  of mine -- Herbie Robinson from  Cleveland -- a bosun's mate -- it  seemed he was asleep but when I  reached over to waken him, he bobbed  in the water and I saw his body upend  because he'd been bitten in half  beneath the waist. Well Chief, so it  went on -- bombers high overhead but  nobody noticin' us. Yes -- suicides,  sharks, and all this goin' crazy and  dyin' of thirst. Noon the fifth day,  Mr. Hooper, a Lockheed Ventura swung  around and came in low. Yes. He did  that. Yes, that pilot saw us. And  early evenin', a big fat PBY come  down out of the sky and began the  pickup.  That was when I was most  frightened of all -- while I was  waitin' for my turn. Just two and a  half hours short of five days and  five nights when they got to me and  took me up. Eleven hundred of us  went into that ocean -- three hundred  and sixteen got out. Yeah. Nineteen  hundred and forty five. June the  29th. (pause) Anyway, we delivered the bomb.

Quint has just finished his story, and we are looking acr the quiet night sea to the Orca slowly circling in the ni the warm light in the pilot house barely revealing the fi of the three men inside, the red and green running lights winking along the ship's flanks. We hear the distant boom and drawn-out hoot of a whale.
What the hell?
It's a whale out there.
There's a brief, eerie pause. Quint breaks the silence by muttering into song, which he slowly swells.
(singing) Show me the way to go home... I'm  tired and I want to go to bed. I had  a little drink about an hour ago,  and it went right to my head. (etc.)
Gradually, Hooper and Brody join in, and the pilothouse  becomes a warm cozy place.
The Orca and its song in the night. In the foreground, th barrel and strobe light flash up into view, and behind th the big dorsal fin surfaces, and glides ominously towards the ship.

The song is continuing, and we hear the barest hint of a  scraping sound from the hull deep beneath the men. Quint' eyes abruptly narrow as his sensitive ears are the first hear the abrasion of his ship. Things vibrate on the shel Quint stops singing, Hooper and Brody continue a duet. Th scraping repeats, and Hooper now senses it. He drops out the song, leaving Brody singing solo.
(quietly, to Hooper) Start the engines.

As Brody hears this and is about to stop singing, the boa is suddenly bumped from below, and the gentle scraping tu to a violent assault somewhere on the understructure of t vessel. Water bubbles up into the hold. Brody starts, and looks at the radio. He is about to move towards it when  Quint's urgent instructions stop him.
He's busting the shaft! Start the  pump!
Where...?
The bilge pumps. There --
He leaves Brody in the pilot house, and runs onto the dec grabbing his M-1 rifle as he goes. Brody hits a switch an we hear the pumps starting.
Hooper is on the flybridge, starting the engines, but the diesels sound wrong.
Cut the engines!
Hooper does.
Rudder bearings?
The boat is assaulted again. Quint fires over the stern,  emptying a clip into the water.
(to Brody) Get up forward! Watch for him!
Brody moves cautiously up to the bow.
Keep your eyes open, Mr. Hooper!
Hooper stands ready on the bridge, Quint pacing the stern deck.
Nobody sleeps! Nobody.
He jams a fresh clip into the M-1. The men scan the seas  around them. Quint resumes their song, louder this time,  more defiant.
(sings) Show me the way to go home... I'm  tired and I want to go to bed. (etc.)
Hooper and Brody join in from their respective positions.
The men in place, singing, the water sparkling towards th horizon, the stars twinkling above. The sound of a distan whale in distant counterpoint.

Brody is at the wheel on the flying bridge, while Hooper Quint have a hatch up on the stern, and are working toget to repair the damaged rudder controls torn loose by the s Hooper is bucking the steel rod, while Quint is hammering away at the joint, trying to drive a new pin. The engine is idling. Bits of iron clutter the deck, alon with a few rough, outsized tools and greasy rags and gask
More left rudder! More! Left hand  down now, Chief.
Brody tries to comply.
(shifting his grip) Lemme get a better angle on it. Now.
Quint hammers again.
He's bent the housing. You can hear  it.
And we can. The Orca's diesels are no longer smooth. Brod suddenly sees something, and points.
The barrel is surfaced directly ahead of them, just off t port side. They are drifting up to it.
The barrel!
The strobe light winks at them. Quint holds up a hand:   "Quiet!" Everything stops as they watch the barrel coming slowly u on them.
It's him.
He takes a killing lance from the rack. Hooper gets a  boathook.
He's under the keg. Careful --
Hooper leans out gingerly, snagging the barrel with the h It bobs lightly in the water, an innocent bystander. Hoop shifts his pole, takes hold of the rope, poling it in.
(suspicious) Easy -- just want to goose him up.  The minute he runs, drop it or you'll  lose your hands.
Hooper gets the line and starts hauling it up. No resista It comes easily over the transom into a coil on the deck. He and Quint exchange looks.
Here -- gimme. I don't see what he's  been doin'.

Both men are draped over the side, their chins almost tou the water on the aft side. From the opposite starboard  direction, fully unfastened from the barrel, comes the Gr White. First the fin, then the conical nose and the upper border of wide, grinning teeth. It knifes through the wat in absolute silence, propelling itself with tremendous sp toward the unsuspecting men.
His instincts shine -- as does his newly-acquired sense o direction.
(top of his lungs) Shark! Starboard!

They turn just in time, and a long spine-stretch saves th from instant decapitation. The Great White passes the tra the harpoon still in its side and trailing five feet of c off cable. It rolls on its side and looks at them as it  passes. Past the stern the huge tail lashes out, ripping the rope out of Quint's hands, shearing a huge swath through the p peeling it off like a plane, taking one of the bronze let out of "Orca." The shark begins an arc to sea, its fin cu the water, and starts circling the boat. Quint notices hi cut hand, palm bleeding, realizing how close he came to l it.
(to Hooper) Haul in that rope -- it'll foul us! (then to Brody on the  bridge) Start the engine!
The diesels start with a terrible grinding.
Easy! It'll tear right out!
(hauling) The shaft is giving.
Hooper slams the hatch, kicks the tools to one side, clea the deck for action once again.
(on bridge) That's it! Radio in for help!
Shut up! Just pump her out!
(coming down off the  bridge) Yeah, Captain, as soon as I make a  call.
Brody heads for the radio in the pilot house.
A perfectly terrible look comes over him. He raises up an starts after Brody. Brody disappears into the cabin. Quin pauses outside and sees:
his calloused hand grabs it up fiercely.
Brody picks up the radio, flicking on knobs and lights on the complex console.
Beg your pardon --
Quint appears, silhouetted in the hot light of the door,  raising his bat.
Duty first and pleasure after --
looking up in horror, covering his face.

Quint brings down the bat with all the strength he can su Crash! Sparks fly, lights blink and go out, plastic and sections metal ricochet all over the cabin as Quint demolishes the ship-to-shore radio. Quint takes a happy breath, winks at Brody and hands him bat.
Excuse me!
Brody's adrenaline turns his fear into rage. His glasses cracked or broken by flying pieces of radio. He seizes th bat, and pound the shattered radio for emphasis.
Some great idea! Now where are we?   Some goddamn skipper you are. You're  certifiable, y'know that? You're a  real treat! Certifiable! Bananas!
His tirade is interrupted by an urgent bellow from Hooper
Pointing at the fin.
Coming right to us!
No -- comin' right at us! Slow ahead,  he'll hit us head on -- (the engine clanks) Slower! Throttle back ---
(raising harpoon) Hard to port!
Hooper pulls the boat into a tight turn and Quint has a s at the upward rolling flank. He sinks it with careful  precision.
Try shakin' that out!
Brody emerges from the cabin as the rope zips overboard, the barrel, changing over, catapults into the air before  plunging into the ocean in a cloudy splash.
(shouting to Quint) Did you get him in the head?
(to Brody) No! No! No! (to Hooper) Swing around! After him!
Hooper can see the fin racing ahead of the barrel. Diving down. Up again -- Quint prepares another iron. Brody is  digging in his bag. He comes up with his 2" .357 service  revolver.
More gas... go to half! Get me right  alongside him --
The engine thuds and knocks.
(shouting down) We can't rev it up this high --
Suddenly the barrel gongs into the side of the Orca.
Watch it!
Hooper skillfully avoids the speeding rope.
Atta boy!
Quint leans to one side, harpoon over his head. The Great White breaks water and...
Take two, they're small!

He sinks it deep. We hear shots. As the new rope whips ou Brody can be seen standing on the gunwale, in regulation  police combat pistol stance, holding his .357 in both han firing at the shark's head. Quint shakes his head in amused disbelief at this, as the barrel goes over.
(shouting at Brody) Don't shoot him any more! He's crazy  on his own blood already!
I can't stand here doing nothing!
Order in the court!
He has seen the two barrels pop to the surface.
(racing over) Three'll do it! He's havin' trouble  with two!
He yells to Hooper and Brody as he swings behind the cont
Grab yourselves a couple of poles!
Quint steers "Slow Ahead," engine protesting, as he maneu toward the moving barrels. Quint peers down, steering clo and closer.
Get ready! Now snag 'em!
Together Brody and Hooper hook a barrel-rope and hold on dear life as the shark changes course.
Pull in the ropes and tie 'em onto  the transom -- free ride.
Brody and Hooper pull in with all they are worth as Quint helps out by wheeling in a circle. He laughs to himself,  enjoying the spectacle.
securing the rope to a cleat but allowing the barrel to h overboard. Brody ties his now-perfect bowline adjacent cl
The boat is jarred violently from side to side as the  underwater force of the Great White jerks and heaves them and fro, up and down, side to side...
are both torn off their feet as the boat is thrust forwar
sees the fin ahead. It is pulling the boat.
Get tired! That's the idea! Here's a  little reverse for you!

The shark leaps partially out of the water, and the sight both horrifying and awesome. Its jaws break water, snappi at the ropes that have him snarled and frustrated. Quint throws the Orca into neutral and shouts down:
Haul in -- watch the prop!
With that, Quint slides down to the prow, putting another shaft onto his gun, finding satisfaction in its heft and  balance. The shark can be seen directly ahead, threshing  closer.
Now! Untie 'em! Quick! He'll tear us  to pieces.
He fires the iron, and the shark veers downward in a gush shower of spray.

They are trying to untie from the cleats, but both ropes stretched too taut. They jump out of the way, falling fla on the deck as the ropes sweep over them, knocking over  objects, skeetering across the deck. A tight jerking moti and the Orca is dragged through the water -- backwards. A much too fast. Water is splashing up over the transom in backward wake. The engines groan and complain.
Damn head is too far away. He's too  big.
Wrenched to one side, Quint is knocked from his feet.

A moment of slackness, and then a great surge of raw stre The rope snaps the cleats off, screws and splintered wood spraying -- and the barrels fly over the water. They disa beneath the turbulent grey surface. The three men, breathing heavily, bruised and pouring swe look out at the blank water.
Pop -- pop -- pop. One, two, three, the barrels surface - ready for more.
(amazed at the shark's  strength) He can't go so deep. Not with all  those on him.
Brody looks down at his feet. There is salt water up to t shoe tops.
What about us?
(mentally assessing  the damage) Have to pump her steady, s'all.
The barrels start a wide circle, each cuts through the wa pushing a wave before it and leaving a wake behind.
(to Hooper) Follow him -- (to Brody) You start pumpin' out here.
Quint tosses Brody the hand pump, then picks up his M-1, checks the load.
(on bridge) He's heading under -- !
(incredulously) No way! He can't!
The barrels approaching the Orca dip below the surface, o two -- three.
Where'd he go?
Brody looks around. Hooper on the flying bridge searching all directions. Quint is looking more appalled every seco
(helplessly) He can't stay down with three barrels  on him! Where is he?!
Have you ever had one do this?
(and he means this) No!
Booming thud at the keel. Brody slides on the wet deck an Quint loses his footing, falling into Brody's arms.

head_text.subj: WITH HOOPER ON THE FLY BRIDGE

text: It seems the only place out of reach of the shark. Quint  climbs up, Brody following him, reloading his pistol. Just then, the barrels pop up ahead, veer left, and duck  under.
Follow him!
He's under!

head_text.subj: BRODY AND HIS POINT OF VIEW

text: There! (points wildly)
The barrels have surfaced and we see the monster shadow  sliding under the Orca, seemingly endless. Violent scrapi sounds.
He's trying to sink us!
(to Hooper) Dead astern! Zig-zag!

Quint is grimly silent. Brody senses that Quint is in the fight of (and for) his life. The Orca taking evasive action. But the three barrels are closing the gap, the engines coughing and missing, destro themselves with every rotation of the damaged shaft. BRODY
He's chasing us! I  don't believe it.
Hooper is jamming the throttle forward, but the engine is pounding and knocking wildly. The barrels circle and move in. Quint has his rifle ready.
(suddenly giving Quint  the wheel) Hold her.

He leaps to his gear, trying desperately to get his dart  gun. Just then, the shark attacks, breaking water and rising o the boat like a rocket; snout, jaws, pectoral fins, belly falling sideways. A vast spray drenches the men. Quint fi into the belly, the bullets pocking the smooth whiteness.
(loading) Keep him there! Keep him!

The Orca shudders from side to side. From Hooper's point view we can the shark gripping the transom in his jaws,  shaking the boat as he saws his massive head from side to side, trying to tear a chunk out of the very hull. Quint reloaded and is firing into the fish. Brody has a wicked  pointed gaff, and is swinging wildly at the snout, gashin and gouging it, trying for the eyes. The killing lust is all three men.
Throttling back!

The boat surges, the shark gives a final unbalances wrenc and disengages. The dorsal fin circles off, beginning a w loop around the boat. The engine quivers and dies, the boat without power, roll half awash, a wounded victim. The fin dips, the barrels follow, the shark disappears be the waves. There is complete silence.
In the dead quiet, we can hear the lap of waves against t hull, the hoarse panting breathing of the men, the pings pops of the cooling, dying engines.
He eyes the stern. Huge cracks and broken timber testify the fury of the attack.
(very quietly, to  Hooper) What can that gun of yours do?
Power head with 20 ccs of strychnine  nitrate. If I can hit him. I can  kill him. But I gotta be close.   Very close.
(the awful realization) You gotta go in the water...
Quint and Hooper are assembling the shark cage, its shiny bars the only undamaged things on deck. Brody is working  too, bolting the sections together.
(in command now) Rig the cable to the roof eyebolts.

The men are speaking in near whispers, quiet in the silen that surrounds them. Hooper is in his wet suit, adjusting weights, mask, tanks, etc. The cage is standing in the st Quint runs a line from the gin pole to the roof section. Hooper climbs in though the top.
Take me up.

Brody cranks the winch, hoisting cage and Hooper into the air. Quint balances the gin pole lines, Hooper crouching the cage, examining it for stresses; satisfied, he holds his hand. Quint puts the spear gun into it.
He examines his weapon, checking the power load, with the big wicked-looking syringe head uncapped to reveal its ra point.
Lower away, Chief. (then, to Quint) Try and keep him off me till I'm  under.

Hooper inside, looking out the bars of the cage, gives Br a reassuring smile, then pops his mouthpiece between his  teeth and checks his regulator. Brody steps back, and wit Quint guiding the cage, begins lowering it off the gin po boom arm into the sea alongside the boat. Brody and Hooper stare at each another as their faces pas Hooper sliding down into the cold grey ocean. As Hooper disappears beneath the surface, Quint and Brody exchange a long look between them.
Submerging. The sky, horizon, water line, clean fresh sea air then... the magnificent innerspaces, with bubbles  sparkling in front of us.
as he floats to twenty feet Hooper never stops looking ar 360 degrees. He removes the rubber guard from the needle waits.
Their turning heads tell us that the barrels are still  circling. Suddenly, both heads stop turning.
The barrels have come to a stop. Delicately, they change  course and meander toward the lowered cage.
His back is to us. He is just now completing a visual swe and turns, eyes front into closeup and: fixes wildly on  something monstrous... and fascinating.

The water is clear and shafts of sunlight streak downward the blue. From the deep gloom -- diving slowly, smoothly comes the shark. It moves with no apparent effort, sinuou beyond comparison. As it nears the cage, it turns, and it ghastly length passes right in front of him: first the sn then the jaw, slack and smiling, then the black eye. Hooper tentatively reaches out. It is too far for the  strychnine pole. The vinyl flesh is pocked with bullet ho iron scars, gaffing hooks and strange open wounds that ti the passing currents with pink.
The trailing barrels gong and scratch the keel of the Orc above. Brody and Quint leap back.

The shark has vanished into a cloud of rising silt. Hoope expecting the shark to attack out of that same general  direction, braces himself, pole extended through the bars breathing faster, straining his eyes into the gloom and.. we see that the shark attacking from behind him. The cage is sent careening. Hooper grabs the bars for dea life. The shark has grabbed the steel struts in its bruta jaws, shaking the cage relentlessly from side to side, be the bars like clothes hangers. Hooper can't turn the poin end of the pole around, his body jammed as far away from non-rational attacker as possible. Hooper is trapped. The shark withdraws to get some running room then charges again. The bleeding snout thrust deeper into the yawing b the jaws snapping and twisting, two feet from Hooper's to the tail thrusting it forward. Hooper drops the strychnin pole between the bars and it tumbles slowly toward raptur depth. All the shark needs is one more good thrust before separa Hooper at the waistline. Through frantic bubbles Hooper  fumbles with the overhead hatch cover, kicking up and out the cage. The shark backpedals with its tail, but the bro head won't shake loose. Hooper rushes downwards, after the strychnine pole.

The shark twists free of the cage and arrows downward aft Hooper. Hooper nearly recovers the pole. Again it slips from his  frightened grasp and this time disappears into a narrow a Hooper turns and looks up. The Great White is lunging at him, twenty feet above.
One of the barrel ropes snakes around the cage rope and p taut.
Turning to meet the monster which -- though held back for moment by the snarled rope -- now surges forward.

The Orca is listing dangerously aft, the ginpole bent alm to the breaking point. Brody is in a frenzy trying to hau up the cage. Quint attaches the end of Brody's rope to a  hand-winch. The ginpole is splitting.
Let go of it!
The pole gives way, the rope whipping down on the gunwale the pulling of the tonnage below is tipping the Orca, dra it, but Quint won't give up the winch. Brody hauls on the rope barehanded.
maneuvering downward, away from the jaws... Suddenly the  crazed shark veers upward for the surface.
The winch is working faster now, Quint demonically windin it in. The crushed cage bangs against the hull then break water. Brody is horrified. The cage is empty! QUINT (a horrible scream)
He's comin' up -- !

The shark breaks water right beside the Orca, rising with great whooshing noise. It rises vertically, towering over blocking out the sun. The pectoral fins seem to reach for The shark, in all of its monstrous glory, falls onto the  stern of the boat with a shattering crash, narrowly missi Quint and Brody. It drives the stern underwater, the ocea pours in over the transom. The jaws snap from side to sid Brody flounders backwards away from it.
He is clinging to the mast for dear life, as the ship beg to tilt to stern, and everything starts to break loose ar him.

The giant jaws are snapping irresistibly at everything: g chunks of wood torn out of the deck and superstructure. Deck chair, irons, rope, gear, beercans, bottles, Brody's bag, all are food for the insatiable maw blindly churning away. Quint is clinging next to a rack of lances: he is enraged this ultimate violation of his territory. He snatches up lance and hurls himself at the shark with a wordless bell The great head weaves side to side, the deck is at a  treacherous incline, slippery with blood and seawater. Qu footing falters and slips, he stumbles at the Mouth of He the big teeth seize him and snap. Quint's roar of rage and pain is choked off as his body i clamped between the grinding, sawing teeth, and his head legs suddenly contort as the shark's teeth meet across hi torso. Blood gushes onto the deck. The remnants of his bo tumble from the shark's mouth. Brody sees the horror, hears the screams -- in his  desperation, he tears loose one of Hooper's remaining air tanks, and hurls it at the monster. It tumbles into the b well, wedging across the back of the mouth, the thick ste blocking the cruel jaws. The shark's head shakes even more violently, trying to cl the cold iron, but the tank is in to stay.

head_text.subj: DECK OF THE ORCA, LISTING BADLY

text: To avoid sliding into the jaws, Brody scrambles on the ti deck, bracing himself in the cabin door to avoid pitching down into the bloody mouth. He fights his way into the ca already a shambles. Below him, on the deck, the shark lunges again, shifting  weight so that the boat in now stern down, and listing to the side. Water from the sea pours into the cabin. Another lunge by the shark. The huge snout and jaws slam against the doorframe, blocking escape, bloody, gnashing. More seawater. To stay in the cabin is to go down with th ship. Brody clambers as far from the shark as he can, against t forward wall of the pilothouse. He sees the window Hooper used before. It's blocked by barrels and debris. He break the side window highest above the water, edges out onto t battered bridge. The shark rolls around, now half in the water. The ship i sinking, the sea is not a viable alternative. Brody climb up into the flying bridge. The shark is still lunging and snapping. Brody is forced climb higher and higher as the ship slowly sinks beneath  him.
He scrambles for his life onto the flying bridge, sees th 1 stuck there, seizes it.

head_text.subj: OVER BRODY, LOOKING DOWN AT THE STERN

text: He is bracing himself, aiming the rifle, taking a bead on the steel tanks, silver gleaming in the bloody shark's mo He fires. And fires. Bullets shatter the shark's teeth,  punching holes in the dripping snout.

With a muffled boom, the perfect symmetry of the shark is suddenly blown apart in a geyser of steel and blood as Br shot hits the pressurized tank. A 30-foot cloud of water, steel, shark and debris covers the sky. A gigantic convulsion hurls the Great White's mangled bod into the sea. The Orca slowly begins to turn over in its  death roll.
The shark's carcass floating down in a cloud of blood and debris. A shadow clouds the waters, and the Orca's mass begins to slip into the frame.
Emerging from beneath the surface, he raises his mask, sp out his mouthpiece and kicks toward Brody.
Brody is holding onto a cushion, barely afloat, relieved shark is dead, yet stunned to see Hooper is still alive. two men share weak laughter, which soon trails off.
Quint...?
No... (notices something
You think we can get back with those?
They swim through the debris, using two barrels as floats as dozens of seagulls feast on shark remains on the surfa
What day is this?
Wednesday... No, it's Tuesday, I  think.
Think the tide's with us?
Just keep kicking.
Y'know, I used to hate the water...
I can't imagine why.
The two tiny, miserable heroes swim ashore as the credits roll.
